Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online posts that show where you are. The website warned that when you say, "Hey, I’m at this place," you are also telling many people where you are, including some you might not want to meet. This shows that sharing everything online can have negative effects. 

The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a large audience, which can seem exciting. However, we often forget that sharing too much can lead to problems. In the past, some early internet users, known as bloggers, explored these dangers. They faced challenges like losing jobs and friends before social media became popular. 

One of these early bloggers was Justin Hall. In January 1994, he started sharing his life online when the web was mostly used by students and scientists. He created a personal blog where he wrote about everything, and many people became interested in his stories. However, when he fell in love and wrote about it, his partner asked him to choose between the blog and their relationship. Hall chose to stop blogging because he felt it made people not trust him.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, who worked in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job, but one day a coworker shared her blog with their bosses, which led to her losing her job. This shows the "online distribution effect," where people say things online that they would never say in person. However, our online lives are connected to our real lives, and we can make serious mistakes if we forget this.

Armstrong's story had a happy ending. After taking a break from blogging, she got married and started a new blog about her family. Now, she is successful as a "mommy blogger," and her writing helps support her family. She learned an important lesson: just because we can say anything online, it doesn’t mean we should.

A while ago, some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? This film mixes documentary and drama to show that there is a lot we don’t understand about our universe. Scientists can sometimes be a bit proud, but even the most confident physicist would not say they know everything about the universe. However, some scientists felt it was important to warn the public about the film, calling it everything from “atrocious” to “very dangerous.” This made me curious to see the movie.

At first, I didn’t understand why there was so much excitement. Various scientists made simple statements about how new discoveries show that the universe is stranger than we thought. But when the film talked about some of these discoveries, I finally understood the excitement. One claim was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. I had heard before that a Japanese researcher showed that the shape of a water molecule could change based on the feelings of people around it. However, the movie only showed pictures of ice crystals that looked beautiful when someone was happy and ugly when someone was in a bad mood. Many people find this kind of evidence convincing because it is clear and easy to understand. But scientists often respond with skepticism, saying, “Give me a break.” 

I understand their point. The idea that water can be affected by thoughts is amazing and could mean there are new forces in the universe. But before we get too excited, we need good proof that this is true. Pretty pictures of crystals are not enough. The real issue is that the movie’s claims were not strange enough. For example, water molecules might have properties linked to a mysterious energy that is causing the universe to expand. This idea is supported by many years of research in labs and observatories around the world.

In fact, scientists are making discoveries that show the universe is stranger than we ever thought. Astronomers have found that the universe is made of an unknown type of matter and is pushed by a mysterious force called “dark energy.” Other discoveries are also surprising. Neuroscientists have found that our awareness of events happens about half a second after they actually occur, but we don’t notice this delay because our brains edit it out. Anthropologists believe they have found where modern humans first appeared and how they spread across the world. Some theorists even suggest there are connections between life on Earth and the design of the universe.

Despite what some people think, science is not finished. In fact, we seem to know less than we thought. Many natural events may never be fully understood. The ideas of chaos and quantum uncertainty show that there are limits to what we can know. Some of the best theoretical physicists are trying to create a “Theory of Everything” that would explain all the forces and particles in the universe with one equation. Overall, many of us believe that the universe can be described in one word: incredible.

To put it simply, I find writing novels difficult, but writing short stories is a joy. If writing novels is like planting a forest, then writing short stories is like planting a garden. Both activities work together to create a beautiful landscape that I love. The trees provide shade, and the wind makes the leaves rustle, sometimes turning them a bright gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and their colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, showing us the change of seasons.

Since I started my career as a fiction writer, I have often switched between writing novels and short stories. My routine is this: after finishing a novel, I want to write short stories. Once I complete a group of short stories, I feel ready to focus on a novel again. I never write short stories while working on a novel, and I don’t write a novel while working on short stories. Writing these two types of stories uses different parts of my brain, and it takes time to switch from one to the other.

I began my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I started writing short stories. I didn’t know much about writing short stories back then, so it was challenging, but I found it very memorable. I felt my fictional world grow, and readers liked this new side of me as a writer. One of my early stories, “Breaking Waves,” was included in my first collection, Tales from Abroad. This was how I began as a short-story writer.

One of the best things about writing short stories is that they don’t take long to finish. Usually, it takes me about a week to write a short story (though I can spend a lot of time revising it). Writing a novel, on the other hand, can take a year or two, which feels very long. Sometimes, I wonder if I will make it through writing a novel. So, writing short stories gives me a nice change of pace.

Another great thing about short stories is that you can create them from the smallest ideas – a thought, a word, or an image. It’s often like jazz music, where the story goes in its own direction. Plus, with short stories, you don’t have to worry too much about failing. If an idea doesn’t work out, you can just move on and remember that not every story can be perfect. Even famous writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn’t write a masterpiece every time. This thought comforts me. 

I learn from my mistakes and successes in short stories and use that knowledge when I write novels. In this way, short stories are like a testing ground for me as a novelist. It is hard to experiment in a novel the way I want to, so without short stories, writing novels would be even harder.

My short stories are like soft shadows I have left in the world, small reminders of my feelings. I remember where I wrote each one and how I felt at that moment. Short stories are like signs to my heart, and it makes me happy to share these personal feelings with my readers.

At its simplest, science is related to philosophy, but it also helps us cure diseases. Science has made our lives easier, but it can also be dangerous. It tries to understand everything from tiny ants to the vast universe. Science has influenced poets, politicians, and thinkers. Its beauty is often seen only by those who study it deeply, and its dangers are often misunderstood. People sometimes overestimate or underestimate its importance, and the mistakes made by scientists are often ignored or exaggerated.

The history of science is full of conflict. Old ideas are often changed or completely replaced by new ones. Just like in music, new ideas are sometimes laughed at before they become accepted. Scientists can be jealous and angry, and the history of science shows that conflict is common. This book will show how scientific ideas have changed not just science, but also how we think about many things. While science has practical uses, we will focus on the ideas themselves.

Science is always changing. There is always a scientist who is proving another scientist wrong. Most of the time, these changes do not disturb society. However, sometimes big changes challenge our established beliefs. For example, in the 1600s, science described the universe as a giant clock. Now, physics questions some basic ideas, suggesting that we can change the universe just by observing it, and we do not fully understand our most basic concepts.

Some people think that the changing nature of science shows it cannot explain the universe. But when science changes, it usually helps us understand and predict nature better. For example, Isaac Newton explained more than the ancient Greek thinker Aristotle, and Albert Einstein explained even more than Newton. Science may make mistakes, but it keeps moving forward. 

At the end of the 1800s, many physicists thought there was nothing important left to discover. Then came new discoveries like radioactivity, X-rays, and the electron. Biology has also made many discoveries. Today, some people believe we are close to finding a complete theory that explains everything about the universe. 

Science is not just a fun activity. In the last 200 years, we have gone from just observing nature to controlling it in some ways. Sometimes, we have disturbed nature without fully understanding the consequences. It is important for everyone, not just scientists, to understand scientific advances because they will shape the future for our children. Science is now a key part of how we think about and shape our future. The decisions made in science can affect many things, including health and the future of life on Earth.

From around 2015, after many years of growth, big publishers started to say that ebook sales had stopped growing or even decreased in some cases. This raised questions about the future of ebooks in the publishing industry. One publishing executive even said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments, making his company lose faith in the value of printed books. 

Even though it seems clear that ebooks and printed books can exist together, people still ask if ebooks will replace printed books. Whether people are trying to predict this or deny it, the idea of books disappearing continues to spark our imagination and create strong discussions. Why is this idea so strong? Why do we see ebooks and printed books as competitors, even when evidence shows they can coexist? The answers to these questions go beyond ebooks and show us how we feel about change and new technology.

In my research, I have looked at how the idea of one type of media replacing another often happens when new technologies are introduced. For example, when television was invented, many people thought radio would disappear. However, radio found new ways to be used, like being listened to in cars and on trains. The idea that books might disappear is not new either. In 1894, people thought that the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This pattern has happened many times. Movies, radio, television, hyperlinks, and smartphones have all been said to threaten printed books at different times.

Some people believed that if books disappeared, it would lead to a decline in culture. Others thought that ebooks would bring a better future. The idea of books disappearing often comes up during times of technological change. This idea reflects our mixed feelings of hope and fear about new technology.

We form emotional connections with different types of media as they become important in our lives. Many studies show that we can feel close to objects like books, televisions, and computers. For example, people might name their car or get frustrated with their laptop. When new technology, like e-readers, appears, it changes our relationship with things we have grown attached to. As technology changes, we often miss what we used to have. This is why there are industries that focus on older products and technologies.

For instance, when the printing press became popular in 15th-century Europe, people wanted original manuscripts. The change from silent to sound movies in the 1920s made people nostalgic for the older style. The same thing happened when photography changed from analog to digital and from vinyl records to CDs. E-readers have also made people appreciate the physical qualities of printed books, even their smell. 

This should comfort those who worry about printed books disappearing. However, the idea of media disappearing will continue to be an interesting story about how technology changes our lives and our feelings about change. One way we deal with change is by using familiar stories, like those about tragedy and endings. The story of books disappearing reflects both our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our lives and ourselves.

For a year and a half, I woke up every weekday at 5:30 AM. I brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how some of the greatest thinkers from the last four hundred years managed their time to do their best work. I looked at their daily lives—when they slept, ate, worked, and worried—to show their personalities and careers. A famous French writer, Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin, once said, “Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.” I believe, “Tell me what time you eat, and whether you take a nap afterward.” 

This book is not just about the creative work itself, but about the daily habits that help people be creative. I also share my own struggles: How can you do meaningful work while making a living? Is it better to focus on one project or to work a little each day? When time is short, do you have to give up things like sleep or a clean house, or can you learn to do more in less time? I don’t have all the answers, but I share examples of how many successful people faced similar challenges. 

The title of the book is Daily Rituals, but it is really about people’s routines. Routines can seem boring, but they can help us use our time, willpower, and optimism better. A good routine can help us focus and avoid being affected by our moods. The psychologist William James believed that having good habits allows us to focus on more interesting things. Ironically, he struggled with procrastination and could not keep a regular schedule.

This book started because of my own procrastination. One Sunday, I was supposed to write a story for a magazine, but instead, I was cleaning my workspace and making coffee. I am a “morning person,” so I decided to look online for information about other writers’ schedules. I found many interesting stories and thought it would be great to collect them. This led to the Daily Routines blog I started that day, and now this book.

The blog was simple; I shared people’s routines from biographies and articles. For the book, I gathered more detailed and researched information while keeping it interesting. I let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from their letters and diaries. In some cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. I want to thank the many biographers, journalists, and scholars whose work helped me. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section for those who want to read more.

Howard became a palaeontologist because of a change in his family’s plans when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, said they could not go on holiday to Spain anymore because of rising interest rates. Instead, they rented a small house on the English coast. One rainy August afternoon, Howard found an ammonite on the beach. He had always wanted to be a palaeontologist, and by the end of university, he knew what kind he wanted to be. He was interested in the very early history of life, not in dinosaurs or the Jurassic period. He studied small creatures found in grey rocks.

When he finished his doctoral thesis, he worried about finding a job. He believed in himself and knew he had good potential, but he also knew that deserving a job does not always mean getting one. When a job opened at Tavistock College in London, he applied, but he did not expect much.

On the day of his interview, the professor who was supposed to lead the panel had a fight with his wife. He left home upset, crashed his car, and ended up in the hospital. The interview happened without him, and a colleague who did not like Howard’s professor took his place. This colleague helped Howard get the job, even though Howard did not know him. At first, Howard was grateful, but later he learned that it was not because of his skills. He felt a little disappointed but was mostly happy to have the job and do the work he loved.

Howard often thought about how organized his work life was compared to his personal life, which could be chaotic. Sometimes, unexpected things could change everything, like when someone stole his briefcase with his lecture notes at a train station. Angry, Howard went back to college, called to postpone his lecture, and reported the theft. He then went for coffee and met a colleague who was with a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. 

During this meeting, Howard learned about a new collection of fossils that needed to be studied. This could be a great opportunity for him. Because of the theft, he changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students on a trip to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.

Charles Spence is a professor at Oxford University in the UK, and he is very open to trying new foods. He even has ice cream made from bee larvae at home, which he says tastes a bit nutty and floral. Spence and his team are working on making bug-eating more acceptable. He studies how our senses work together to create the flavors we taste. This research affects what we eat and drink, from big food companies to fancy restaurants.

Spence's book, The Perfect Meal, co-written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, shares interesting facts about food. For example, did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant usually enjoys their meal the most? Also, we tend to eat about 35% more food when we are with one other person, and 75% more when we are with three people.

Spence's lab is simple and not very high-tech. It has soundproof booths and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work with chefs who cannot pay for research. Much of his work is funded by a large food company. In the past, some people thought that research funded by companies was not real science. However, now it is important for universities to show that their work matters to people.

Spence is helping food brands reduce salt and sugar in their products. This is important for keeping customers healthy. Many companies make these changes slowly so that customers do not notice. Spence explains that when people know about the changes, they focus on the taste and often do not like it as much.

Spence met famous chef Heston Blumenthal while working on a project for a food company. They worked together to create a dish called "Sound of the Sea," which uses sound to enhance the dining experience. Spence has found that different sounds can change how we taste food. For example, high-pitched music can make food taste sweeter, while lower sounds can make it taste bitter. Soon, an airline will match music with the food they serve.

At home, Spence has unique dinner parties. One time, they ate rabbit with the fur still on the cutlery. Another time, they used remote-controlled lights and tested different drinks with headphones. For Spence, home and food events are just extensions of his research.

Our brains are working harder than ever. We are bombarded with facts, false information, and rumors that we need to sort through to find what is important. At the same time, we are doing more things ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents helped us book flights, and salespeople assisted us in stores. Now, we do most of these tasks on our own. We are trying to manage many responsibilities, like our jobs, families, hobbies, and favorite TV shows, often with the help of our smartphones. These devices encourage us to fill every free moment with activities.

However, there is a problem. We think we are multitasking, or doing many things at once, but this is a misleading idea. Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT, explains that our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching quickly between tasks. Each time we switch, it takes mental effort, which can make us less efficient. 

Multitasking can increase stress hormones in our bodies, leading to confusion and difficulty thinking clearly. It can also create a desire for constant stimulation, making it hard to focus. The part of our brain that helps us concentrate can easily be distracted by new things, like shiny objects that catch our attention. This means that the part of our brain we need to stay focused is often sidetracked.

Research shows that just the chance to multitask can hurt our ability to think clearly. Glenn Wilson, a psychologist, found that trying to focus on a task while seeing an unread email can lower our IQ by almost 10 points. This loss of focus is even worse than being tired. Russ Poldrack, another neuroscientist, discovered that learning while multitasking can send information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework while watching TV, they may not remember the information as well.

Multitasking also involves making decisions, like whether to reply to a text message. Making many small decisions can tire our brains, making it harder to make good choices about important matters. Many business leaders and scientists agree that email is a big problem. It’s not that email itself is bad, but the huge amount of messages we receive can be overwhelming. One neuroscience colleague’s son said his father’s job is to “answer emails,” which is not far from the truth. We feel we must respond to emails, but it can be hard to do that and accomplish other tasks.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking concrete into pieces to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help other fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right position to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people thought these questions were not important. Animals had behaviors that led to clear results, and scientists only studied those results. The idea that animals have thoughts, feelings, and morals was seen as silly. But this has started to change. Research on bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has begun to explore animal emotions. This change has reached popular science books, like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". This has started a debate that may never be fully answered: do animals have consciousness? This leads to another question about conscience, which is a person’s sense of right and wrong that guides their actions.

In a recent experiment with cows, researchers found that cows who opened a locked gate to get food showed more happiness by jumping and kicking than those who had the gate opened for them. If cows enjoy solving problems, what does this mean for how we raise and eat beef? While the observations are clear, people disagree on what they mean. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, who wrote "Second Nature," believes we should stop eating meat because of this new research. He thinks humanity is close to a big change in ethics, similar to when slavery was abolished. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, believes we should rethink how we understand animal thinking. He thinks animals have a simpler understanding of the world than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail believes we should not project human feelings onto animals. These three views may never agree because the main issue is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Since it is very hard to define consciousness, can we ever really know what it is like to be a bat?

Balcombe describes an important experiment he did that suggests starlings, a type of bird, can feel depressed. In a study at Newcastle University, starlings were divided into two groups. One group lived in nice cages with plenty of space and water, while the other group lived in small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid unpleasant worms from another. But when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the starlings in nice cages would eat. Balcombe concluded that living in a bad cage made the starlings feel negative about life. Balcombe, who has worked with animal rights groups, has a strong opinion. He says, “We look back with disgust at a time of racism. One day, our view of animals will be the same. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger.” 

If Balcombe were the only one with this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning shares similar ideas. Manning has written a textbook called "An Introduction to Animal Behaviour." He says, “What we are seeing is a swing in ideas. In the early 20th century, some people thought animals thought just like us, and then there was a reaction against that. Now we are moving back to the idea that animals have feelings. But this is a complicated topic, and we should be careful about listening to academics with strong personal opinions.”

Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or hear more deeply. Adrian West, a research director at the Edward de Bono Foundation in the U.K., believes that arguing can help us find the truth. While technology helps us store and process information, there are worries that it also changes how we solve complex problems and makes it harder to think clearly. West points out that we are often surrounded by poor quality ideas and opinions, which can confuse our thinking. More information does not always mean better knowledge or decisions. 

According to the National Endowment for the Arts, fewer people are reading books, and this decline is getting faster. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, thinks that focusing more on visual media, like videos and games, may hurt our critical thinking skills. She says that people are multitasking and not concentrating on one thing. However, we still do not know exactly how technology affects critical thinking. 

Technology can have both good and bad effects. For example, a computer game might help improve critical thinking, while browsing many links on the internet might distract us from deeper thinking. Greenfield has studied how technology changes the way we think. She believes that reading helps us think better and use our imagination, while visual media like video games and TV do not engage our imagination in the same way. However, she also found that some visual media can help with processing information quickly. 

Unfortunately, many young people may not reach their full potential because they do not spend enough time reflecting or analyzing information. How society views technology affects how we think about critical thinking. There is a debate about whether video games are good or bad for children. James Paul Gee, a professor of educational psychology, argues that video games can actually be good for learning. He says that games like Sim City and Civilization teach important skills like decision-making and analysis in a fun way. These games allow players to explore ideas that they might not be able to in real life. 

In today’s digital world, as reading and math scores go down, it is important to understand how technology affects our thinking and analysis.

When Matthew Crawford is not writing about how we should live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He chose this job after he became unhappy with working in an office and for social policy organizations. His first book was about the good things about manual work. His latest book talks about how to deal with modern life. He got the idea for this book when he was shopping and saw advertisements on the credit card machine while he was entering his pin number. Crawford realized that it is becoming harder to avoid these distractions. What we want to think about at any moment is personal, but we often cannot choose this because of things we do not notice. It is getting more difficult to think or remember conversations. Because people want to avoid being interrupted, they often stop talking to strangers.

Crawford says we now experience the world through things like video games and phone apps, which often try to manipulate us. These things reflect our desires and can take over our attention. Many people are worried about this. For example, office workers complain about emails but still spend their free time checking them. Studies show that just seeing a phone can make it hard to focus. There is no clear evidence yet that our attention spans have changed, but people are more aware of other things they could be doing. Some think this problem is caused by technology, but Crawford believes technology has made it easier for us to focus on ourselves. With so many choices, it is hard to control our attention, which affects our social lives. People prefer to text friends instead of talking to them in person. Crawford argues that by only interacting with screens, we might lose important connections in society.

He gives an example from his gym. In the past, there was one music player for everyone, which could cause disagreements. Now, people listen to their own music with earbuds. This has made the gym less of a social place. Real connections often happen when people have different opinions and work through them together.

Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we need to reduce noise and distractions in public places. More importantly, he believes we should engage in skilled activities to connect with the world better. He mentions cooks, ice-hockey players, and motorcycle racers as examples of people who deal with real things. No video can replace the feeling of a hockey puck on ice or the gravel under a motorcycle. These activities require good judgment and the ability to interact with others.

Crawford says that when we engage with the real world, we see that manufactured experiences are not as fulfilling. This does not mean everyone should become a chef, but it is important to use our judgment. There are many benefits to this, including professional satisfaction. Constantly fighting distractions can be tiring and make it hard to focus on what is important. In contrast, paying attention to one thing can help us pay attention to other things too.

"What do you do for a living?" This is a common question in small talk, and many people answer it with a few words about their jobs. But if you are a philosopher, like me, it can be a bit more complicated. Saying you are a philosopher can sound a bit showy. It is better to say you study or teach philosophy. Many people think that being a philosopher means you know some special truth, but that is not true. Philosophers are just like everyone else.

One reason people have this idea about philosophers is that they often judge what others do and celebrate thinking. The Greek philosopher Aristotle believed that a life spent thinking deeply was the best kind of life. While not all modern philosophers agree with him, philosophy is still seen as connected to deep thinking.

Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that "the unexamined life is not worth living." This means that just going along with what everyone else thinks is not satisfying. Our ability to think about the world helps us control our lives and make our own choices. However, living an examined life does not mean you have to read many difficult philosophical books. It just means paying attention to the everyday experiences that shape our lives.

Philosophy does not have to be about being away from society to think clearly. In fact, examining our lives can be very practical and should be shared with others because it is important for a good life. 

Another reason people misunderstand philosophers is that academic philosophy has become more separate from real life, especially for those who do not have formal training. This is not only the philosophers' fault; universities often focus on expensive journals and evaluations that make it hard for philosophers to share their ideas with the public. Because of this, philosophy can seem far away from everyday life.

Many philosophers used to challenge this view, but now some accept it. The academic world has created a situation where philosophers are isolated. As philosophy has become more focused on specific debates, it has become harder for people outside those areas to understand. In some cases, philosophy seems to have withdrawn from society.

I sometimes call myself an "ethicist" because I work in ethics, which is the part of philosophy that looks at human actions. Recently, I feel this title does not fully describe my work because ethics is often linked to formal rules and laws. There is a new area in philosophy called applied ethics, which looks at whether certain social practices are fair or not. 

The job of an ethicist today is to decide if an action is "ethical" or acceptable. These are important questions that I think about often. However, philosophy is more than just this. For example, a discussion might start by asking if illegally downloading movies is wrong (it is) and then move on to questions about responsibility, our views on art, and how consumerism affects us. 

In this way, philosophy helps people think more deeply about the actions and behaviors that shape their lives. Sometimes we might find out something we already knew; other times, we may realize our beliefs are hard to defend. By examining these ideas, we can do something good for everyone.

Food lovers, chefs, and anyone who enjoys food might think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. However, in the past, discussions about food have often been used to talk about other ideas. When philosophers discuss eating, they usually use it as a way to explain something else, like gaining knowledge. Sometimes, conversations about food seem to be about food, but when we look closer, we see they are really about different ideas.

One interesting philosopher is Epicurus, who believed in seeking pleasure and avoiding pain in many areas of life. His name is now often connected with enjoying food and drink. You can see his name in restaurants, food shops, and recipe websites. These businesses likely hope to attract customers by linking their products to a famous philosopher.

Food is also a social and cultural experience. The food we eat comes from history and is shared with people in our communities. These communities help us grow and share food. We interact with food more than with any other product, making it a good topic for philosophical discussion.

When food is ready, critics start to talk and write about it. But why do they have such a special role? One philosopher pointed out that tasting food is not a special skill; food critics are just better at describing what food tastes like. This area has not been studied much, as most research on perception has focused on sight. This should change.

Another important part of food is its beauty. We often talk about art and music being beautiful, but we don’t usually talk about the taste of food in the same way. Some philosophers believe that, because of modern cooking, food deserves to be discussed as art, like sculpture or poetry. However, food is eaten and gone, while art can be enjoyed over time. This makes it hard to say that food is truly an art form.

There are also many ethical questions about food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, local, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? Our answers often show our beliefs about what is right or wrong. Philosophers will always question why we choose what we do, and discussing these ideas about food is important.

Cooking at home and in restaurants can be very different. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests because of their personal relationships. In a home kitchen, everyone shares food and time together. In contrast, professional cooks work for their employers and focus on the food itself. Their kitchens are not open to everyone, and their relationships are more about work than friendship.

A recent essay called "Diplomacy of the Dish" looks at how food and dining can help connect different cultures. This happens in two ways: first, we learn to appreciate others by enjoying their food, and second, we build friendships with people from other cultures by eating together. This practice has a long history in international relations. The essay includes many interesting examples and stories that make this part of food philosophy come alive for readers.

Rob Daviau is a game designer from the US who creates ‘legacy’ board games. He felt that the traditional board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore, so he thought about how board games could change. He wondered if they could have a story and if choices made in one game could affect future games. 

He took a classic game called Risk and made a new version called Risk Legacy. In this game, decisions made during play have lasting effects. Players might have to tear up cards, change the game board, or open new packets with different rules at important moments. The game is played over several sessions, and players can hold grudges that affect the game. Daviau said, “You could point to the board and say: ‘Right here! You did this!’”

Later, he worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players work together to cure diseases. His next game was called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was very successful, SeaFall was seen as a big test for the legacy format because it was a new game, not based on an earlier one. In SeaFall, players become sailors in the 16th to 19th centuries and explore a new world.

Designers of legacy games must think about all the choices players can make to keep the story interesting. To do this, they use play-testers to see how the game works. Jaime Barriga, a play-tester for SeaFall, said it takes a lot of time. Sometimes the game works well at first, but then it can break after a few rounds, and they have to fix it.

Legacy board games were not expected to become very popular. Daviau thought it would only appeal to a small group of people. He said, “I thought I would be known as the guy who did this weird project.” However, many players, like Russell Chapman, really liked the idea. He believes it is one of the biggest improvements in game design in years. He said, “It’s a new level of commitment, intensity, excitement.”

Another fan, Ben Hogg, said that the fun of a new adventure is more important than worrying about how long the game lasts. He mentioned that people don’t usually watch the same movie twice in a row; they want a new experience. Legacy games bring a storytelling aspect similar to video games.

Daviau originally wanted to be a television writer but ended up in advertising and game design. He still loves telling stories. Matt Leacock, the creator of Pandemic, compared making legacy games to writing a novel. He said you need to know how you want the story to start and end, but you also need more than just a basic plan.

Daviau is excited to see how others will use his idea, but he also thinks that gamers will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, the studio manager for SeaFall’s publisher, believes the legacy format has changed how people think about board games.

One night not long ago, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He crawled across the floor and squeezed into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was exciting and was shared a lot online. People enjoy stories like this because they like to think that animals are similar to us. Octopuses are especially interesting because they are very smart and look very different from humans. 

Octopuses can do amazing things like open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells for protection, and even play games. Some scientists think that saying animals are like humans is not scientific. Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, believes that we often ignore the human-like qualities of animals. He calls this "anthropodenial." He has studied animal intelligence for many years and found that animals can do many things that we thought only humans could do, like remembering the past and the future, showing empathy, and understanding what others want.

In the past, people believed that animals were smart enough to be put on trial for crimes. Even Charles Darwin, who changed how we see our place in the world, said that the difference between human and animal minds is just a matter of degree, not kind. However, in the twentieth century, many scientists started to see animals as simple machines that only respond to rewards and punishments. This view became popular at the same time that humans were harming animal habitats and not caring for animals properly.

Dr. de Waal thinks we are starting to change our views about animal intelligence. He believes that animals have their own ways of being smart, just like humans. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hide their food. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might judge us by how well we can change the colors of our skin. If we failed, it might think we are not very smart.

Dr. de Waal is not completely convinced that Inky really knew how to escape to the ocean. He knows that while some octopuses have escaped before, it might be too hopeful to think Inky planned his escape. However, he understands that stories like Inky's help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment with capuchin monkeys to see if they could feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the ones with cucumbers became very upset. This study was published in a scientific journal, but a short video of the experiment made people really believe the findings. This shows how our understanding of animal minds is changing.

Text: 

Robotics, once just a part of science fiction, is now changing our world in a big way. Robots have been used in car and factory work for many years, but experts say we are about to see robots used in many more areas. Many people think robots will take over most jobs done by humans in the next 50 years. However, about 80% of people believe their own jobs will still exist in the same way during that time. This shows that people feel their jobs are safe, but they might not be. Every industry will be affected by robots in the coming years.

For example, an Australian company called Fastbrick Robotics has created a robot named Hadrian X. This robot can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour, while two human workers would take a whole day or more to do the same job. Another example is a robot called Tally, made by a company in San Francisco. Tally moves around supermarkets to check if products are in the right place and priced correctly, instead of cleaning the aisles.

Supporters of robots say that robots cannot fix or program themselves yet, which means new jobs will be created for skilled workers like technicians and programmers. However, some people worry that we should not forget the importance of human skills at work. They believe society is not ready for the changes that will come when human interaction is less important.

Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots are changing jobs. His recent report says that in two years, about one-third of robots will be smarter and able to work with other robots and humans safely. In three years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will create laws about robots. In five years, salaries in the robotics field will go up by at least 60%, but many jobs will still be unfilled because there aren’t enough skilled workers.

Zhang believes that automation will affect lower-skilled workers the most. He advises them to retrain and learn new skills instead of waiting for the government to protect their jobs. He says that people cannot expect to do the same job for their whole lives anymore.

New technologies will also create new types of robots for homes, which will be more advanced than anything we have seen before. These robots will live with us and interact with us in new ways. This change offers great opportunities for companies, but it also brings challenges, like the need for new rules to keep us safe and protect our privacy.

With many jobs at risk and a global employment crisis approaching, it is important to focus on education. Developed countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) to stay competitive in the future.

Text: George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, once answered a reporter's question about why he wanted to climb Mount Everest by saying, "Because it’s there." This answer shows a common feeling: many people want to know why someone would take such a dangerous risk. Some might feel inspired by his answer to follow their own dreams. It suggests that climbing can be about adventure and fun.

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called "Games that Climbers Play." He described seven different climbing activities, from playing on small rocks to climbing high mountains, each with its own rules. He believed that the way climbers approach a climb depends on the rules of the specific activity. This idea has become popular in climbing discussions in the West, appearing in climbing magazines and conversations.

Many climbers love climbing because it gives them a sense of freedom. However, climbing can also feel very limiting. For example, being stuck in a tent during a storm is not what most people think of as freedom. This creates a contradiction in climbing. But some argue that having fewer choices can make life simpler, which can also feel like freedom.

When asked "Why climb?", US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He believes that climbing is part of human nature. We like to take on challenges and test our limits, even if it is risky. The joy we find in climbing is more about our biology than just logical thinking.

US academic Brian Treanor also wrote about climbing, saying it can help develop important qualities like courage, humility, and respect for nature. He believes these qualities are especially important in today's world, which often avoids risks. Climbing can help us grow and live better lives outside of climbing.

Another idea is that climbers who do not depend on others or technology must be fully committed to succeed. Expert climbers Ebert and Robinson stirred some debate by saying that climbing alone is harder and deserves more recognition than climbing with a team or using tools like bottled oxygen. Some worry that this view might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.

We can also look at climbing from a different perspective. Many climbers talk about being "in the moment" or "going with the flow." The physical effort, the focus while climbing, and the instinctive problem-solving are all key parts of the experience. Some argue that climbing is similar to Zen philosophy, which teaches how to find peace of mind. This idea offers another reason why people are attracted to climbing.

Over the last sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became very important in classical music. He was a serious person who studied and recorded many famous European piano works. He wrote and performed a lot, but he did not teach many students. People who knew him saw a fun side to him, but he rarely showed it during his concerts. His life was a busy mix of studying, traveling, and performing.

About four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take this seriously. He had very few students and did not see a reason to start teaching now. He remembered a famous pianist saying, “You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.” However, he was impressed by Kit, who was about 14 years old. When Brendel listened to Kit play, he thought, “I have to make time for him.” Kit played very well and from memory. He even gave Brendel a CD of his performance, which was beautiful and showed great skill.

As Brendel steps back from performing, Kit is starting to become more known. Kit, now 19, is always busy learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis, all while his mother watches over him. He also composes music. Brendel believes this is important because writing music helps you learn to read it better. He noticed that Kit has an amazing memory and can read music very well. Kit listens carefully to his own playing and understands Brendel’s instructions. When Brendel tells him something about a piece of music, Kit can apply it throughout the entire piece.

Brendel is careful not to raise expectations for Kit. He gets upset when newspapers call Kit the next great pianist of the 21st century. He thinks this kind of attention can be harmful. Like many talented young musicians, Kit can play some pieces very well, but he still needs time and experience to improve in other areas. It would be unfair for critics to expect him to be perfect.

Now at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed in his retirement. He shares that when he was young, he did not want to be famous quickly, but he wanted to achieve certain goals by the age of 50. When he turned 50, he felt he had accomplished most of those goals but still wanted to do more. Although he cannot play as physically strong now, he still has many ideas and pieces in his mind that he has never played. He enjoys this new phase of his life.

When I was a child, I thought gardens were beautiful places. My grandad’s garden was by a river and sloped gently down to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I believed all gardens were like this – peaceful and quiet. 

Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a fancy greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic covering broken glass. At home, my father was often quiet. He had a sense of humor and liked to say things like, “It’s immaterial to me,” instead of just saying, “I don’t mind.” Deep down, he might have felt disappointed with his life. He left school without any qualifications and became a plumber, which he didn’t love. He wasn’t very ambitious, although he and my mother once thought about moving to Canada, but it didn’t happen. 

My father was good at fixing things around the house. He could build bookshelves or cupboards very well. My parents only moved house once, but my mother liked to change the furniture often. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when a piano came into the house. I wanted to like it, but it seemed scary. I only liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mother said they were too fancy and they disappeared while I was at school. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister took lessons instead. When I asked my mother why, she simply said, “You’d never have practiced.”

Of the places to explore – moors, woods, or the river – I always chose the river. I could imagine a different world there. With a fishing net over my shoulder and old sandals on my feet, I would walk along the riverbank looking for a good spot. I would take off my sandals and leave them with my picnic while I looked for fish to catch. After some failed attempts to keep the fish alive in the yard, I returned them to the water.

I wanted to leave school as soon as I could, but it seemed impossible until one day my father said, “There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.” In that moment, he surprised me. He might have preferred if I became a carpenter, but I like to think he saw my love for gardening. Even though he didn’t like gardening himself, he had watched me enjoy it and hoped I would succeed if I worked hard.

Lawrence MacEwen is on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck, and I am with him. A strong wind is blowing, and it feels like we might be blown off the cliff and into the ocean below. But Lawrence’s sheepdog, Tie, comes close, and Lawrence gently pets him. Despite the strong wind, Lawrence feels comfortable on his island.

Lawrence shows me around his neighborhood. He points to the north and shouts, “That island is Eigg. The one next to it is the Isle of Rum, which gets a lot more rain than we do.” I see dark clouds pouring rain on Rum’s big mountains. “Beyond Rum is the island of Soay,” he adds. 

Suddenly, Lawrence says, “I have sheep to move,” as rain starts to come our way. We walk down the hill, and he tells me more about the island: Muck is three kilometers long and one and a half kilometers wide; the geese here eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. 

While herding the sheep, Tie is not doing a good job. Lawrence tells him, “Away to me,” which means to go to the right, but Tie goes straight through the flock, causing confusion. Lawrence sounds disappointed and says, “That will never do.” Tie looks ashamed.

The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm. Their son Colin manages the island cottages, and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby enjoy that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. “They go out and come back only when they are hungry,” Mary says.

However, living on the island has its challenges. For example, electricity is not always available. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to come on. The next morning, I see Mary preparing breakfast with a flashlight. I also have no mobile phone service. Mary tells me, “You can get a signal on the hill, but most people stop using their phones after a couple of days.” So, I do the same.

Life on Muck is surprising. A boat arrives with groceries and three musicians who come to play a concert in the island’s tearoom. The islanders enjoy the music and tap their feet along. That night, while sitting by a warm fire as it rains outside, Lawrence tells me how he met Jenny. “Her father bought a small farm on the isle of Soay without even seeing it. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.” I ask if Jenny knew how to run a farm. Lawrence replies, “She had good typing skills.”

I go to bed listening to the rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, as most of the food comes from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I carry it back to Mary’s kitchen. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it is delicious.

The next morning, I worry about my ferry ride to the next island. Many ferries had been canceled in the past two months because of rough seas. If my ferry does not come, I would be stuck on Muck for two more days, which secretly, I would not mind at all.

The game design industry used to be mostly for computer scientists and self-taught individuals. It was often seen as just a hobby for young people, but now it is taken seriously. This change may surprise some, but experts in the industry are not surprised. However, getting into this field is not easy. Creating video games, especially those based on movies, requires many team members and a lot of skill and hard work.

Jim Donelly, a spokesperson for an online games magazine, says that it is hard to make progress in big companies or to influence major games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever. They need not only top-level directors but also people who can design systems and individual parts of games.

So, how can you enter this competitive industry? Many companies prefer candidates with a degree in computer science, but Jim believes that the best way is to make games. He says, "You won’t get a job if you haven’t made something." Game design is more than just a job; it is a way of life. You need to create to be successful.

Another expert, John Field, agrees that making games is important but says it is more complicated than it seems. Many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry's requirements. It takes creativity, technical skills, and the ability to adapt to changes in the industry.

Can you succeed on your own? John says it is possible but difficult. A good postgraduate course in games can help you and provide support. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all types of entertainment and culture. They may have worked for a few years after graduation but realize that games are their passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and understand the variety in this field.

Networking is also important. To succeed in games, like in many other areas, you need to make connections.

The old image of a young boy playing video games has changed. Now, games attract a wider audience, including families who play together on interactive consoles. Smartphones also offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of potential for growth in this area. Games are not just for fun; they can also be great tools for learning, and he sees many opportunities for the future.

Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he never forced me to do it, and I am thankful for that. I had a friend whose dad was very strict. He always told him, "You can’t do this, you can’t do that." My friend could have been a good player, but he lost interest in football and stopped playing. I am happy that I did not have the same experience. 

When I score a great goal from far away, some people say it is just luck, but it is not. I have practiced taking long shots since I was young. You can only score amazing goals by practicing. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes, I see young players bumping into each other, but I learned the right techniques. When I teach kids, I always tell them to enjoy learning new skills.

At school, I played many sports, like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know now that a good education is important, but back then, football was all I thought about. The teachers were doing a good job, but I didn’t notice it at the time. I want my son to have a different experience. We are already trying to read him books, even though he is too young to sit still for long. I hope that when he kicks the books around, it doesn’t mean he will be like me.

At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so that younger players like us could play for the first team. He never made a big deal about it, but we all knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A famous TV presenter said, "You can’t win anything with kids." This made us realize how much we needed to improve. Even though we had doubts, we believed in ourselves as a team.

I depend a lot on my close friends and family. Having money can sometimes create problems. For example, people ask me why I let my mother keep working. I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and they would not like to feel like they need my money. My mom is a hairdresser and loves her job, but I enjoy using my money to help them.

I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think. Money does not solve all my problems. After I stop playing football, I want to take a year off to do things I have not been able to do. I want to go skiing the day after I stop playing. I cannot do that now because if I break a leg while skiing and cannot play football again, I would not be insured.

It was because of Sam Carter that we lived at Reef Point. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He offered to help us find a cheap place to live because my father was having a hard time writing there. He couldn’t sell anything, and Sam was worried about losing his clients and money.

During the summer, the beach was empty because sea fogs often covered the sun. Reef Point didn’t get many visitors. The road to it was not very nice, and a nicer place called La Carmella was nearby. Most people chose to stay there if they had some money. Only those who were broke or loved surfing would come to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, many people were at the beach. After being almost alone for months, we were now surrounded by people and activities.

My father was busy every day trying to finish a script. He was stressed and not in a good mood. While he worked, I often went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty started to hang around. I tried to chase him away, but he always came back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him some water. My father threw a boot at him, but he didn’t really mean it. Rusty knew this and came closer. I asked my father, “Who does he belong to? He thinks he belongs to us.” My father replied, “You’re wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him.”

Rusty loved the beach. He liked to dig and bring things to me. Sometimes he found things that didn’t belong to him, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, and I had to return them to their owners. He also loved to swim and always wanted to join me, even though I could swim faster and farther. Luckily, he never got discouraged.

That day, after swimming, my father went to Los Angeles to deliver his script. Rusty and I spent the afternoon together in the sea. As the sun began to set, it got cooler, and we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. One surfer caught my attention. She was very good and made the others look clumsy. When she decided to stop, she rode in on a final wave.

“Hi,” she said. “Why didn’t you join us?” 
“I don’t have a surfboard.” 
“You could get one.” 
“I don’t have any money.” 
“You’re British, right? Are you visiting?” 
“No, I live here.” 
“Is your father American?” 
“No. He came here to write a film script based on a novel he wrote.” 
“Really? Have I heard of him? What’s his name?” 
“Rufus Marsh.” 
“You mean, Tall as the Morning?” I nodded. 
“I read that book from start to finish.” 

She looked at me with new interest. I realized that people were friendly but only showed interest when I mentioned Tall as the Morning.

Violet Hetherington was feeling worried as she stood in a long line at the dock in Southampton. She remembered her friend Annie's advice: "It's better to arrive late at the docks. If you come too early, you will just wait around." Annie was experienced in traveling, but this time her advice was not helpful. 

After some time, an announcement came over the loudspeakers saying there was a problem with the computer system. The mood among the waiting passengers became tense. Many had paid a lot of money for this cruise, and they were unhappy about the delays. Violet started to feel like she had made a mistake by coming on this trip. 

When she checked her bag, she realized her phone was missing. This was more frustrating than the long wait. Without her phone, she couldn’t call the taxi company to see if she had left it in the taxi. All her important numbers were saved on her phone. 

Behind her in the line, there was a friendly couple. Violet asked them if she could use their phone to call her son Harry. She left a message for him to ask their neighbor, Kristina, to check if her phone was at home. If it wasn’t, she would have trouble finding the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her felt relieved, but she didn’t tell Harry that. He often thought he was wiser than her, while her younger son, Daniel, was more understanding of her mistakes.

Finally, the line started to move, and Violet handed over her travel documents to board the ship. When she entered the ship, she felt disappointed. The inside looked like a cheap hotel with shiny fake wood, big chandeliers, and busy carpets. 

She followed the signs to the elevators, which were crowded with tired passengers. As the elevator moved up, it stopped at each floor to let people out. When she finally reached the twelfth floor, she was happy to find her room had the balcony she had wanted. She had worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a better deal, she had decided to pay more to make sure she had a nice view of the sea.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he did not know he was starting to uncover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof wanted pictures for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, but he found 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer with a great talent for capturing interesting moments. Since then, Maloof has collected many items related to Maier’s life and work. In his home, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes.

One morning, Maloof looked around at all this and felt he was close to something special, which happened by chance. “When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,” he said. “I could have easily sold it all to someone else.” For a while, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They spoke to families who had hired her as a nanny and talked to people at the shop where she developed her film.

Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person and had a unique style. She often wore large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. “On her day off, she would have her camera around her neck and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,” said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. “She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.”

Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. Even though she was not very social, she walked the streets with her camera and sometimes interviewed people on audiotape. She seemed to be very dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist who followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “Nothing stopped her.”

Maier’s work is pure art; she did not create it for money. Her photos often show women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract scenes. “What is interesting about Vivian is that she has so many amazing pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style or borrowed ideas from others.

Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever go through all the negatives he has stored in three tall, fireproof cabinets. The funny thing is that he was not really interested in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. “As I learned more about photography and looked at her work again, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It was the people and the street scenes,” he said. “There was so much more to her work than I thought, and I realized I had something very important. Now our goal is to share her name and get Vivian Maier into the history books.”

When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it has not completely succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very popular, but she seemed calm, especially for someone in her twenties. She had just arrived from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. 

Eleanor shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass. The official looked at it and asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s. A series of crimes have happened, and a group of 12 men has come together to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past gave her characters many chances for complications and misunderstandings. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a good chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she said it feels nice to come from a small country because everyone feels part of her success. She received a lot of support from people back home. However, she finds it annoying when people think her book is not serious or philosophical.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, where each part is half the length of the one before it. This makes the story speed up as it goes along. I asked if it matters if readers notice these patterns. She said she wanted to create a book with interesting structures that readers could notice if they wanted to.

Even with its unique structure, The Luminaries is still an exciting murder mystery with a gripping plot. Surprisingly, she did not plan the story in advance. She would write herself into difficult situations and then see how creatively she could get out of them. One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers.

We also talked about her love for TV dramas, which often have cliff-hangers and different points of view. I asked if she would be interested in writing for television. She said that could be fun. 

Eleanor spoke with excitement about her work and New Zealand. She noticed that being in a different place changes her imagination. She understands why writers leave New Zealand for busier areas to be around more people. But for now, New Zealand will still be her home. I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either making things in his dad’s garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has been building acoustic guitars by hand. He says, “I am still amazed by the guitar. How can two pieces of wood make such a beautiful sound? Different types of wood create different sounds, and it still surprises me.”

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. Instead of saving money for one, he decided to make it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood changed the sound of the guitar. Jonny had already built model boats and planes with his brothers, so he was used to making things. His father taught them how to use tools, and Jonny had also repaired instruments for his friends.

Jonny’s first bass guitar turned out well, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a career at that time. He was also interested in painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he went to university to study architecture because it involved design. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out because he felt it wasn’t right for him. He realized that building guitars was like making sculptures, but with sound. He thought it would be a more practical career than pure art because people actually use the guitars.

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time to earn extra money. He sold his first guitars for just the cost of materials, but as he became known as a good guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, after almost forty years, he says he is “still scratching a living.” He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the beginning, Jonny worked hard to get known. He went to music festivals on weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his guitars because he didn’t think about money much. Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers today in the UK. When he started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good. But now, UK-made guitars have a good reputation.

Jonny thinks new guitar-makers should take courses to learn valuable skills. However, he also believes that learning by trying and making mistakes is very important. He says, “You should look at other instruments, see what works and what doesn’t, and try different things. If you make the back of the guitar too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you learn from someone else, you might only learn one way, but if you teach yourself, you learn everything.”

When we talk about English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a common tradition, and many writers mention a famous quote from Dr. Johnson, an English writer from the 1700s, who said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This is still true today. 

Many people try to explain why the English talk about the weather so much, but they often get it wrong. They think that English people are really interested in the weather itself. For example, the American writer Bill Bryson says that English weather is not very interesting. He points out that in England, we don’t have extreme weather like tornadoes or big storms, which makes it less exciting.

However, another writer, Jeremy Paxman, disagrees with Bryson. He believes that English weather is interesting because it is always changing. He says that even if we don’t have big storms, living near the ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

I think both Bryson and Paxman miss the real reason why we talk about the weather. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather. Instead, they are a way for English people to connect and start talking to each other. For example, when someone says, "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" they are not really asking about the weather. These phrases are just ways to greet someone or to keep a conversation going.

Talking about the weather is like a social tool for English people. There are specific situations when we use weather talk. Some people say that English people talk about the weather all the time, but that’s not true. We usually talk about the weather in three situations: as a greeting, to start a conversation, or to fill a pause when there is silence. 

Because we use weather talk so often, it may seem like we are obsessed with it. An English conversation might start with a weather greeting, then move to more weather talk, and return to it again when there is a pause. This is why people from other countries think that English people only talk about the weather.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall that is 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, even though they could have chosen to go to Spain, Greece, or France. They wanted to know why the wall was built, but Alice felt she did not have good answers. 

When she could not find a good historical novel about life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started her new career as a writer in 2001. She felt nervous but excited about this big change. She said, “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very tiring. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it is not as exhausting.” Alice’s former teaching colleagues were jealous because she still connects with children through her stories.

Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction. She noticed that many books for teenagers focus on negative experiences or are completely fantasy, like Harry Potter. She wants her books to be different. Alice always taught English and History together, using stories like the Tale of Troy to make lessons interesting. She loves the moment when a child goes from being bored to being interested. “I enjoy having bored children because it challenges me to make them engaged,” she said.

Alice started writing her first novel because she saw a need for it, but she was also inspired by the idea of her two sons leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. “I had been teaching for 25 years, and I didn’t want to spend my summer on a course I thought was unnecessary.” Before she could join the course, she had to send in a piece of her writing. Just a few days before leaving, she quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. After three hours and 30 pages, she sent it in and was accepted.

During the course, other students read her story and gave her great feedback, encouraging her to publish it. With only her report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was very important for her writing. She said, “My mother-in-law thinks we are rival authors, but I believe we work well together. He helps me improve my writing, while I like to add more scenes.” This is the difference between a fiction writer and an editor.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. They would race to the same finish line in the beautiful Yorkshire Dales in northern England.

“I’m excited for this,” Jonny said at the start line. “I’ve never done anything like this before! The views are beautiful, and it’s very cold, so I can stay warm in the car.” Alistair, dressed in warm cycling clothes, was also eager. “Honestly, I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he will make it. I might stop for tea halfway!” 

The race began at Semerwater lake and would finish at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is 350 meters up. This would be easy for Jonny in the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill right away. They quickly shook hands and started the race.
