Alistair rode off on his bike, while Jonny got into his car and drove away. The big question was: who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence quickly faded. Just 15 seconds into his drive, he had to stop for a big tractor on the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he said to the cameraman. “If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving. Meanwhile, Alistair was struggling with the steep hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, while sheep watched him curiously. Finally, he reached the top and was ready to speed down the other side.

In the car, Jonny faced more challenges. The roads in Yorkshire are old and narrow. He had to slow down to get around a tight corner and drive through a small stream on the road. Once he was clear of the last village, he raced straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close they were to each other.

As Jonny drove fast towards Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard and then suddenly had to brake as he reached the finish line. Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they said no, he raised his arms in celebration. “Yes!” 

A few minutes later, Jonny arrived in his car. “Well done,” he said to Alistair, feeling disappointed. “I’m really upset.”

The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it, hearing only the echo of your own shots. The well-kept grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowd all create a calm atmosphere. This silence helps me focus on my game. 

In a tennis match, my biggest challenge is to ignore everything except the game and the point I am playing. When a point ends, the silence breaks with applause, cheers, and people shouting my name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me closely or the millions watching around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the most important match of my life.

I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the biggest tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice in the finals. Losing in 2006 was not too hard; I was just happy to have made it that far. But losing in 2007 was very difficult. I knew I could have played better, and it hurt more because I had a chance to win. I cried for half an hour after that match. 

Toni, who usually criticizes me even when I win, surprised me by saying there was no reason to cry and that there would be more chances at Wimbledon. I told him he didn’t understand; I felt it might be my last chance to win. I know that a professional athlete's career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment is important, but some moments are more important than others, and I had missed a big one in 2007.

However, Toni was right in the end. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I felt confident that I had learned from my past defeat. The best sign that I was ready was my strong belief that I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with my family and team, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them to avoid the topic, but they understood that I was already focused on the game in my mind. From that moment until the match started, that focus was mine alone.

In early April 1957, a young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, Jane became famous when Britain’s National Geographical Society published articles and made documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. She also wrote popular books, including award-winning children’s books and the bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements.

Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on her personal life rather than her work. People see her as a girl who loved adventure, a woman who wanted to be with wild animals, or a feminist in a man's world. These views do not fully show what she has accomplished. 

Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading scientist in her field because of her important research and the many students she has taught who have become influential in biology. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people thought wild chimpanzees were very dangerous, and they did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. They also did not realize that chimpanzees have emotions similar to humans and that their social lives are like ours. 

Jane's book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," published in 1986, is the most important work on chimpanzee research. Her long study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves as humans.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of becoming a biologist. When she was five years old, she disappeared one autumn day. The police and her family searched for her. After a long search, she came back with straw in her hair and clothes. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voice of a funny 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, an amusing old Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says, “so I had to learn how to say many medical terms quickly.” 

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there is more to it. You have to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many well-known people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions, but often they don’t get the roles because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a regular acting career. During the course, she did some work singing jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I didn’t study drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a big part.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.”

Adult female actors often provide the voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter than male actors. There are complicated rules for hiring child performers, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create different sounds and collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound happy. When I work on animation, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors is great.”

The competition for work is strong, and a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached the top of her profession through hard work as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and showing it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they teach all types of voiceover.” She also thinks a love for human sound is very important. She describes herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over me, and I’ll speak like that for hours or even days,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in many different voices.”

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people give up these dreams and choose more practical jobs, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. It seems silly to think you can make a living by drawing simple pictures, but some people do.

Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college and after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that needed political cartoons about local issues. I created some ideas, and they bought them. Soon, I was making enough money to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be many more cartoonists than teachers. The barriers to becoming a cartoonist are low, but it is still a hard job. You should only try to be a cartoonist if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and gives you time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have to make a living with your art. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I take on all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

Now, let’s talk about the business side of being a cartoonist. In the past, many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But now, most cartoonists have to be entrepreneurs. This means you not only create the work but also sell it. If you are comfortable with this, you will do better. I have seen cartoonists with average creativity but great business skills succeed more than those who are very talented but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it could actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar from Japan. I usually don’t like to throw things away, so I was surprised that I wanted to get rid of it. I took it to the dump and was about to leave it there when a young man came up to me, looking confused. He asked, “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. After that, I felt sad about my decision for a long time.

A few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I opened the email from a man named Keith Rushton, who restores guitars. He told me, “I have your electric guitar.” It had been sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found my name on a label on the guitar and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy I almost cried. His price was very fair.

I remembered how my dad always put name labels on my things, including my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle. But I didn’t make much progress, so I switched to electric guitar, playing easier songs. At that time, punk music was also popular, and anyone could be a rock star, even if they weren’t great at playing.

When I opened the box that Keith sent me and took out my old guitar, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt amazing. It was smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put the strap over my shoulder because that’s how you play electric guitar. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t explain the chords, but my hands just knew what to do. My fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing the strings to play.

Electric guitars are usually played in a band. Now that I’m learning again, I think I should form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves “The Regainers!”

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote my book called Insomniac, which is about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was the only one talking about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep can affect our minds, bodies, and feelings. Many people who have trouble sleeping understand how important sleep is. It is good that sleep is finally getting more attention. 

But what about dreams? I haven’t heard much about them. We often forget our dreams. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss out on the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM sleep, the stage where we have the most dreams. The best and most memorable dreams happen during REM sleep, especially just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM. If someone lives to be 90 years old, they will spend about six or seven years in REM sleep. When researchers take away REM sleep from people, they find that the next night, those people have more REM sleep to make up for it. This shows that dreams are important.

In 1953, researchers found REM sleep, and many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who said that understanding dreams could help us understand our minds. However, later studies showed that it is not that simple. Now, researchers focus more on the physical reasons for dreams rather than the psychological ones. According to Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University, there is not much agreement among dream researchers.

Dreams are important. At a meeting of sleep experts, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study. He found that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than others. He believes that people who are more interested in being creative use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams because films are very dream-like.

But I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Stickgold says that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present. Dreams can help us find new patterns and create ideas that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They come up with unexpected ideas that make sense in a different way. This is what creativity is.

I find that I write better after having intense dreams. Even a bad dream or one I can barely remember seems to help me think better. On those days, my ideas come out quickly, and I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t know how it works, but it does help. 

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complicated world, and everyone needs to think clearly. We need to be creative and flexible in our relationships with coworkers, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, you see a beautiful view of the sea and many empty frames on the walls, along with happy photos of her two daughters. Susie is a well-known copyist artist. She can create copies of famous paintings from the early 20th century and the 16th century very well. She says, “I don’t keep my own paintings. As soon as I finish them, they go.” 

Susie is very popular and has worked as a copyist artist for 30 years. She has painted many famous artists' works, like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that art experts sometimes think they are the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions of pounds, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how long she spends on them. 

Susie does not reveal the names of most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors love art, but others want to show off their collection. One famous buyer likes to say he owns a ‘Van Gogh’ painting, but it is really a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. Susie knows that some collectors keep the original painting in a bank and show her copy at home. 

She is honest about her work. When she copies a famous painting, she tries to make it look as real as possible because she wants to respect the original artist. However, she puts her signature on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real painting, and even though some people make money that way, Susie has never wanted to do that. She knows that people who make fake art often get into trouble. 

Susie is not rich and has faced challenges, but her life is more stable now. She believes it is not worth risking her good name with collectors and artists. Before becoming a copyist, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden after finishing her art degree. She earned very little money, but it helped her learn important skills and gave her a love for plants. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets about that time, but she is happy to have found a more rewarding job.

When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw well and represent things accurately. She has studied a lot to do her work. She can draw plants and make perfect copies of 15th-century paintings, but she now focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. 

Susie believes that many people think modern art is easy, but she explains that impressionists painted quickly and freely, yet they were also very careful. This combination is hard to achieve. Some people wonder why Susie does not create her own art. They ask if her original paintings could sell for more than her copies. Susie explains that her work comes from years of training, and she earns a good living from it. 

She has tried to create her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked too much like photographs. She thinks it is like living on simple food after enjoying meals from a great chef. Susie is a perfectionist in her work.

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest on it. Since she was a child, sailing was her big passion. She felt a strong connection with her boats, which took her around the world. When she returned to land, everyday life felt unimportant. People wanted to know about her races, but she just wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me her small boat, Kingfisher. She took me into the tiny cabin where she lived and worked for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even counting how many rolls of kitchen paper she would need. Preparation was very important to her. She proudly showed me her simple food supplies, a small gas stove, and medical items. She took great care of her boat because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. A key moment for her was a trip to South Georgia, a lonely island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. This experience made her think differently about the world. She noticed many abandoned whaling stations and felt it was a warning about how we take resources without caring for the future.

When I visited Ellen's office, she was finishing a busy call. She explained why we need to act now to protect the planet. She said that coal, oil, and gas are limited resources that we cannot replace. At first, her message was to use less, but she later realized there was a better way to think about it. Now, she talks about re-using things, like industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, she has been visiting factories and power stations, discussing our dependence on resources that cannot be renewed. She says, "I will never be an expert, but I love learning." She felt she could not ignore the current situation. Compared to sailing, which felt selfish, this work is about finding how she can help the most. 

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people think about and create a sustainable future. She admits she misses the adventure of being at sea, as it is a big part of who she is. At sea, she felt connected to everything and focused on survival. She knows her new message is not as simple as saying, "I want to be the fastest around the world." Although she was once the fastest, this new work is even more important to her.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. He hopes to inspire other kids to go outside and explore nature instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he is a teenager.

Many experienced climbers think it is not a good idea to take a 13-year-old up Mount Everest. They believe that while Jordan may be strong enough physically, he might not be emotionally ready. They also worry that he may not have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. Paul and Karen have heard these concerns before. Paul says, "I know people criticize us, but we have to keep going. We think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow stronger gives me confidence."

I wonder if Jordan is doing this because his father wants him to. Paul says, "This is not about me wanting to be famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought he would do this later in life, but we decided, 'Why not do it now?' We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it." When I ask Jordan why he wants to climb, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal."

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest climber. Now, every adventure is shared online, and people want to break records. This creates a problem for Jordan. Some people think that focusing too much on achievements can take away the fun. But if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to share his journey online, take photos, and give interviews. He has to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it is likely they are not listening to classical music. Many people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I just started studying music, but my classmates know as little about classical music as other teenagers. If you don’t know who created the music, you probably don’t have any of their recordings. This is sad for fans of classical music. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. This is hard to believe.

So, why is interest in classical music going down? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that is the reason. The truth is that classical music does not attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I am not a big fan of classical music. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music can be hard for us. We like fast talking, fast playing, and fast thinking. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Also, pop music talks about things that interest teenagers, while classical music often does not.

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that more people are going to classical concerts now, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why more middle-aged people like classical concerts, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it.

Some people say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids want to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy playing classical music, but it is not what they choose to listen to for fun. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we always choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the car too, so she didn’t hear Bonnie, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother already knew how she felt. 

Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside. It looked confusing at first. Then she saw signs that said: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do that.

A few minutes later, Mrs. Wyndham was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be thrown out soon anyway, so why not just go?” She left the building and walked towards the riding centre, following the sign. 

There was a nice old building for the horses and a big area for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well taken care of, and she could see that right away. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking carefully at each one. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. 

Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best of them all!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a little white. He looked lively, and Bonnie liked that. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition…” The horse’s name was Maverick. 

Suddenly, she really wanted to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle,” she thought. Luckily, the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. Excited, she put a saddle on Maverick’s back and forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. 

When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her old school friends called her Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered that. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said happily. “I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think we could be great friends,” she said. 

She rode around the paddock, feeling the rhythm of the horse. A light breeze brushed past her cheek, making her feel alive. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

I have met Cody Simpson before, and I was impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old from Australia has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? Cody says, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven." He remembers that swimming and surfing were very important to him at that time. He was busy with these activities and had a good life. When he was 13 and in high school, he posted some videos online.

These videos changed everything. He started by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans wanted to see more of his videos on social media. Cody recorded more songs at home and was happy to share them. The response was amazing. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches and focused on his sport. But then record labels contacted him, and he had to make a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the chance. He said, "It was very difficult for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?" 

He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to America. "It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid," he remembers their shocked faces. "I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world." So, Cody packed his bags and moved with his family, giving up one dream to try to make another come true. 

Even though his family stays out of the spotlight and does not work directly in his career, they support him. Cody believes it’s important to have good people around you to stay grounded. Everyone has doubts sometimes. "Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, 'How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?' My little brother is eight years old, and he travels the world and does school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life," Cody admits. "I worry about how this affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do."

Success in any career comes from being willing to say 'yes' to your big opportunity, even if it feels scary. "It all happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, I go to countries I never thought I would visit and play in front of hundreds of thousands of fans. It’s something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won’t last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I squinted and looked upstream at the sandbags that were there to stop the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags last week. I had worked hard with many people from the town to help. But my grandfather didn’t seem to notice.

I looked at the dark water coming from the wood processing factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on both sides, and solid ice further down the river. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t know him. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and put on my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky silver chain, which my famous grandfather had brought back from South America. Only my grandfather, my mom, and I know about this chain. I also have his diary from that trip, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. I touched the chain and went to the kitchen.

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his room. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious because I was wearing my wetsuit. He always saw me in my kayak every morning. I tried to ignore his anger, but it was getting harder. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came over with a kind smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I wanted to say he was always like this, but I tried to be nice to him. When I was younger, he was my hero. He showed me pictures of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang on his wall, along with his medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own picture in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, even though he is grumpy.

Mom smiled. “At least he is coming out of his room more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even in this cold weather!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It will be warmer in South America if I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. I stepped into the backyard and hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her into the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was a painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa's, but it looked different from his other work and was not finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything." 

Jess looked closely at the painting. It showed a river that she didn’t recognize. It might not even be a real river, just a made-up one. The painting was strange and beautiful in a spooky way. The riverbank was very small, with a hint of green that was easy to miss. The pale water seemed to lead to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant scene. Still, Jess felt drawn to it, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice that showed her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: "River Boy." The words felt important to her, but she didn’t know why. 

Then Jess noticed something else. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." 

"Exactly. It’s strange for him to be so specific. But maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." 

"Mum! You should have known better." 

"I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess what he said." 

Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew Grandpa would have said, "It’s not the artist's job to explain a painting. Each painting has its own life and language, like a poem. We either understand it or we don’t. Painting is hard work, and I can’t waste time explaining it to everyone." 

Mum laughed. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." 

"Inspire?" Jess asked. 

"Yes, someone who inspires an artist." Jess understood the word. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the muse wasn’t helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse. He never said the muse was about her. She thought he meant a goddess, not a real person. It was hard to believe anyone, even a goddess, could influence someone as stubborn as Grandpa. 

"He doesn’t need me to inspire him," she said. "He’s been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s knife in my hand, the knife might have gone into the carpet and made a big hole. I’m not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn’t mean to damage the carpet. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me often. 

What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. My Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and it has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and old ladies selling balloons. Now, I keep my collection of shells and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was so happy when she gave it to me!

The problem is, it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to go in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it is the smallest room in the house. It is shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is for Mum and Dad, the back one is for my sister Angela, and the little one over the garage is for my brother Tom. My room is very small, like a broom cupboard. Mum says when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have Tom’s. Then, when Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I will be in my small room for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love how the roof slopes down and how the window is at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. I thought, if I can’t cut the cabinet, why not cut a hole in the carpet? It seemed like a good solution. Dad calls this “lateral thinking.” He always tells us to “think outside the box,” and that is exactly what I was doing!

The novel "The Borrowers" is about a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They "borrow" things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the book, I knew it would be difficult to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should be. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I wanted to avoid criticism.

The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans'. This made filming more complicated. The most important thing was to get the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room, we had to be ten times further away than usual. The crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to show the Borrowers' view. They went through many pairs of jeans!

We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. A big challenge was to create the right shadows when we combined the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We came up with a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we did it.

The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was very surreal. I remember asking them to carry a giant pair of scissors, and they really got into it. The coins we used were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift, which made the crew laugh a lot.

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary that they didn’t need to act. I wanted to get the costumes right, which has been a problem in other versions. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they looked like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to move. She couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would look too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen. It was hard for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how they should look – I made 2,000 drawings by the end. The budget didn’t allow for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly. Once, I filmed a whole scene and then realized there was no film in the camera! But in the end, everything came together, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there aren’t any. I know that soon there will be attention on me. It always happens. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones who ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I wanted to come to this school to meet normal kids. I want to meet kids with parents who have regular jobs, like working in an office or cutting grass. That would be so cool.

I walk into the school office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary looks confused. “Oh,” she says and types my last name on her computer. That’s good because not many people know my last name since my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” she asks. “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” she replies. Then she gives me my schedule. English Literature is my first class. Great! I like English. But I will be late. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look silly trying to find my classes.

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher calling names. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. No one will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my fancy shoes with flowers on them. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses and says, “Desert... McGraw?” “Here,” I reply. The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After explaining the books we will read this year, she lets us talk to each other! All teachers should do this.

“Why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few options for my answer. Should I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or should I say what my dad thinks? He said, “We need a change, Desert, and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose a studio so close to the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, it’s easier to lie. “What does he do?” she asks. I know everyone will find out eventually, but I want some time to pretend to be normal. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care much. Great!

Not only is the average American teenage girl expected to be the president of the Student Council, but she also needs to have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America today. Boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average because being average is not enough anymore. People think that not having big goals is being lazy. 

Kristen Loose, a teenager, says, “Adults often forget how much pressure we have. We have a lot of homework, tests, after-school activities, jobs, chores, and we also want to have a social life.” Even though these stresses are normal for teenagers today, there are still negative stereotypes about them. Some people think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and only care about themselves. While some teenagers may fit these stereotypes, many do not think it is fair to label all teenagers this way.

Kristen Loose believes that many people wrongly assume teenagers spend all their time on their phones and watching TV. She admits she often has her phone nearby, but she uses it for important things, not just for fun. Teenagers use their phones to make their lives easier and to stay connected. Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and to be reachable all the time, which can look like an addiction to their phones. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons.

Now, schoolwork and other activities do not stop when school ends; they need attention all the time. Many teenagers start their day around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish their day after midnight. Their schedules are full of school, after-school activities, family responsibilities, and homework. They have to wake up and do it all again the next day, often getting less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. A survey found that about 20 percent of American teenagers get enough sleep, and 28 percent said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen thinks that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. She does not spend much of that time on social media or TV; instead, she focuses on volunteering. She says, “People think teenagers only care about themselves, but I love volunteering. I want to make a positive impact in my school and community.”

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to prove those stereotypes wrong and make the world a better place. There will always be new generations of students who are making a difference before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US. This town is mostly surrounded by wild nature, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In the last few years, this group has sent over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long-term science project that combines astronomy and adventure, which is why many teenagers join. 

I visited them one weekend in late spring. They were getting ready to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and creates a bright light. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box, there was a camera, a device to measure height, and a thermometer to check temperature changes as the balloon rose. They also put two GPS trackers on the outside of the lunch box to help find it later. 

A gas tank, given by a supporter from another state, was used to fill the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy drove seven hours to get the gas tank. He said, “I didn’t really mind.” For kids in this club, this is normal. Finally, it was time for the balloon to lift off. They counted down, “Five, four, three, two, one,” and the balloon started to rise. Some of the teenagers ran after it with flashlights, trying to follow its path in the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder as the balloon disappeared into the night.

After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky, which was surprising because it was only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. One girl whispered, “We’re the only ones talking.” Another girl replied, “I know.” Suddenly, a meteor shot across the sky.

As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, and the balloon expanded until it was almost the size of a house. Then it popped with a loud noise. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is not much land with people around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. The group’s leader said, “Recoveries are a big part of the program.” They have only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. He added, “Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.”

This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. The leader said, “These students know the Eastern Sierra well. What seems wild to some is just normal for others.” 

In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera did not capture any shooting stars, which was a bit disappointing. However, it gave them a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work above mountains. It was also another adventure story to share with anyone who asked.

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. Her interest started by chance. "My younger brother was really into dinosaurs, which I didn’t care about at all. I helped him with a science project, and when I read an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology, I was amazed. I knew I wanted to pursue this field."

I asked Chloe how she got support for her interest, as Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people back then. "I remember meeting my first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius. He was already famous, even though he was young. I was very nervous, but he was friendly and listened to me. That made me feel more comfortable."

I also asked her about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe frowned and said, "Movies like Jurassic Park have made many people interested in dinosaurs, but they don’t show palaeontologists accurately. We are often seen as strange geniuses or awkward people who can’t talk to others. This is not how our daily work really is."

Chloe explained her job. "I do a lot of different things. I dig up dinosaur bones, spend time in labs studying fossils, and write for scientific journals. Sometimes, I also explain scientific findings to the public, especially to young people. It’s important to help them understand science better. Talking about dinosaurs can get kids excited about nature and other areas of science."

Chloe worked on the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, which helped show dinosaurs more accurately. "The people who made the show knew what they were doing. I only needed to check a few things, like making sure the dinosaurs were the right size and lived at the same time. We attracted viewers of all ages because we have learned so much about dinosaurs recently. The dinosaurs in this show are much more realistic than those in movies like Jurassic Park."

I asked Chloe why she thinks dinosaurs still interest us and why research continues. "I think dinosaurs appeal to our curiosity. They make us want to explore and discover new things. Even though our world feels smaller now, dinosaurs remind us that there is still much to learn. Palaeontology is like time travel."

When you travel by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not “there yet,” even if you keep asking, “Are we there yet?” When you finally arrive, it is not “there” anymore; it is “here.” So, if you think you might be “there,” you should ask, “Are we here yet?” 

Parents often wish they were “there” more than anyone else because kids keep asking this question on long trips. But think about it: wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while enjoying the view outside the window. Meanwhile, one of your parents is in the front seat, giving you juice boxes and cookies, changing the radio, and making sure everything goes smoothly.

But sometimes, things can get crazy in the car. For example, my younger brother, Tim, might put his foot on my side of the seat. I don’t like that, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, we are fighting, and our parents have to separate us while driving. They tell Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This helps for a while, and we can enjoy the beautiful scenery again.

Later, when I try to read, I feel a draft on my arm. The window is closed, so I wonder where it is coming from. Tim is next to me, breathing on me. He is not touching me, so he thinks he is not doing anything wrong. This makes me angry, and soon there is more yelling and swerving in the car.

Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us. When we ask, “Are we there yet?” he sometimes says, “Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.” But if we are still on the highway, we know that is not true. You can tell you are finally “there” when the adults get out of the car and move away from the kids. So remember, if your parents are still close enough to answer your question, the answer is: no, you are not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a place where people can connect without using their phones or other devices. She believes that people should spend time together and talk to each other.

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming or building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by a German designer named Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources with each other. Everyone stays involved and no one feels left out. 

Later, cooperative games were created, where all players work together to win or lose as a team. One popular cooperative game is Pandemic, designed by Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players must work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on a famous book. He remembers feeling scared and excited while playing it with friends. He wanted to create a game that gave people those same feelings.

Leacock has loved board games since he was a child, but he often felt disappointed when games did not meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he started to design his own games. Pandemic became very successful and introduced a lot of storytelling, similar to video games, where players develop characters and the story changes as they play.

The rise of video games has helped make board games popular again. Many people now play games on their smartphones, which has made them more open to playing board games too. Ben Hogg, who works for a game company, says that everyone has at least one game they enjoy on their phone. 

For a while, video games allowed people to play together in person, but then many games moved online, making it harder to connect with others. This led some people to look for ways to play games with friends and family in person again. In John and Zuzi's busy café, it is clear that tabletop gaming has become more than just fun. In our online world, games are now something people can share together in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that hard work and determination are very important in the music industry, even if your career starts slowly. He says his mother was a great singer and helped him learn to play the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was for older people, which influenced his music taste as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song. Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he was good at, and music. He spent his lunch breaks at school learning songs on the piano. He said, “I was good at tennis, but it was not what I wanted to do forever. It was too much hard work.”

At 17, he left school to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who played guitar but did not want to pursue a music career. Jamie told his parents that he wanted to focus on music, even though he had been writing lyrics during his economics classes. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed in music; if he didn’t, he would need to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he got signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, the record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.

Eventually, he found success behind the scenes instead of on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. He did not become famous right away. He said, “I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time for most of my career, but as a writer, I’ve been in the right place.” Writing for other artists is where he really found success. He believes he is one of the main writers that UK labels turn to for new artists. He sometimes has to explain to these artists that wanting to write popular songs is okay. He asks them, “Don’t you want millions of people to listen to your music?” He wants to help them create songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well.

It is nice to hear someone like Jamie talk openly about wanting to write big hit songs. He is not arrogant; he just knows he has a talent for writing number one songs. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his work. He says, “When I go into the studio, we need to aim for the best music of next year. It’s not just about what’s cool; we want to write great modern pop songs.”

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, may not know him because we don’t watch videos of people doing bike tricks. He is a "street trials cyclist." This means he jumps from hard places like roofs or walls to land safely in other difficult spots. People film these stunts and share them online.

I met Tony one Saturday morning at a BMX park. The local kids all know him, and some older people come to tell him he is "an absolute legend." After watching him perform, I agree with them. At first, I was unsure about him, but I was impressed by his bravery and creativity. Before each jump, he explains what he plans to do, and sometimes I can’t believe he will succeed. When I compliment him, he seems a bit uninterested and sad. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to connect with fans. He prefers to focus on doing his stunts rather than talking about them.

Tony thinks that the cameras and social media help him earn money from what used to be just a hobby. He feels that many people are always filming themselves or looking at screens, and he doesn’t always agree with that. However, he is not unhappy about his situation. 

From my experience interviewing top athletes, I have learned that two important things help a child become a great competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These qualities can be more important than talent. In risky sports, it is very important to have mental strength. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he thought were easy challenges. But he got back up and kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He says that those people may care, but they don’t understand the sport. They probably have never tried riding a trials bike and don’t know the technical details. Tony gets advice from experts to help reduce risks.

Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He believes that people are different. Some people are not scared and should not do risky sports. Others can feel fear but still push through it. Tony is in the second group. He feels fear but finds a way to overcome it. He is not addicted to risk; he spends a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes, he rides around for a while to get ready before trying a new stunt. He knows he must stay calm before he jumps. If he fully commits to the jump, he feels confident.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. These include running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, just a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her balance and avoid falling, she used a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. 

Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found out that high-wire walking was very different. “The training was a shock,” Helen said. “I didn’t know I needed to be so strong. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But I had to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!”

On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen stayed calm by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took her 15 minutes. “That was the scariest thing I’ve done,” she said afterwards. “I’m glad it’s over!” However, this experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, kiting, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-fashioned bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and also used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes,” and decided to see the world by bike.

Jeff did not want a regular touring bike. He wanted to build one himself. He thought the most interesting bike would be a penny farthing, so he went to a museum to learn how they were made. After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The best part of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met other cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted using his penny farthing. People were always amazed by it as he traveled further from home.

His worst experience was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got a serious fever and spent ten days in a hostel without medicine. He had no money for a hospital or to go home. Despite these challenges, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

I work at a university in the US with my team to learn more about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast.

We know a lot about what they do during the day, but we don’t know what they do at night because we didn’t have the right equipment. The new scope will give us clear pictures, even when there is no moon, so we can learn more and make better choices to protect their habitat.

It is hard work. There are four of us, and we each work six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some locations and write down every duck I see. The weather has been difficult – some nights are warm, but most of the time it is wet. It is very quiet, so I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. 

I enjoy the challenge, especially when I think about the summer. In summer, we will spend hours in a laboratory looking at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this work. I wouldn’t change it for anything!

Whenever I tell people what my job is, they can hardly believe it. But I’m serious! I spend my days at work eating chocolate! Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure that customers get the best quality chocolate from my company. Every week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate, from our factory. I check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to choose the best ones for the chocolate. 

Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make. I also share samples with my colleagues to keep them happy! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients to work with. It’s great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I am in our food lab, and other times I travel to other countries to buy our raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family, but I love the variety in my job, even more than the chocolate itself!

People often ask me if I get bored of chocolate. I have worked with it for a long time, and I have never felt tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!

Have you ever thought about what it is like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place that teaches young people circus skills. She says that her course is popular because it teaches many skills. These skills include juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which is flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

The course lasts for a year, and students slowly take more risks in each class. Parents can come to some classes to see how their children are doing. Sophia explains, “To have a career in the circus, performers need to do different things. It is important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part of this job is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Staying fit is also very important. Circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and always want to improve their skills. 

Some people think that circus performers get hurt often or that they only work for a short time each year. But the real challenge is thinking about the future. You can only travel and perform while you are young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many former students have started their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. However, Sophia warns that this is not a job for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It is also very competitive, but it is a lot of fun!”

You may not know her name or face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. This means she sings in the background to support the main singer. Many people think backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true. They often have to be even better! People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry.

Mariam says, "What I love about my job is that when I go into the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing. It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might even be a funny song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what the producers ask me to do. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do my job!"

"To do my work well, I need excellent musical skills and the ability to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, and nobody likes that. Recording sessions are already long."

"One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers sometimes do not know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can learn how to make it better."

Julie Deane started her business with only basic knowledge of fashion. She created a successful line of ‘satchels,’ which are traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. 

Before deciding to sell satchels, Julie thought about different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She wanted to make the best choice. When she chose satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Many people said there was no need for them, but Julie believed in her idea.

Julie worked with her family from the beginning. She teamed up with her mother, who had never worked before but was good at business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. 

At first, Julie didn’t know much about fashion blogs, but they became important for her success. She started by selling about one satchel a week. To get more attention, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew. Now, her company makes satchels faster than before. Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity is seen with a satchel next!

While other companies spend money on online ads, Julie uses the internet to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a tough time when another company copied her satchel design, so now she makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff.

Visitors to her office often say it has a positive atmosphere, and people enjoy working there. Julie has a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes the place special.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose how to spend their free time. Vicky liked to do many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to balance training with schoolwork.

As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky thought this looked exciting and decided to try it too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so it was easy for her to go to training after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won many competitions. When she was 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, “I loved winning for many years, but I started to feel tired of it. When the excitement goes away, there’s no point in continuing. Luckily, I found a new job.”

Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. She said, “We work with young people who have never enjoyed sports. The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job and helps young people feel part of a group.” The charity uses famous people to promote their work. Vicky said, “Some people think having a celebrity support a charity is not always good. They believe celebrities do it for their own benefit, which can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.”

Ana Ronson is a singer-songwriter from Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, there was always music in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play.

The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was very nervous, and her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested that Ana join the school theatre club to help her feel more confident. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term.

A year later, Ana's brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song called "Falling Stars" in just three days. She enjoyed writing so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew a lot about music. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, so she wrote a song called "Something to Say" about her feelings. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was happy to see that people loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics.

Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, flew from the other side of Ireland to invite her to join his company. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. But Joss convinced her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was a wonderful night.

Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times in life rather than happy moments because she feels she has more to say then. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how sad it made him. Ana hopes her fans will enjoy her songs, but her main goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on a wonderful trip. I traveled by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit this area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew it was where our great-grandparents lived before they moved to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes!

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. But luckily, the weather was supposed to be good when we arrived. I was busy with work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry said he would take care of everything, so I stopped worrying.

When we got to Canada, we met the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and started our journey. The guide told us that very few people live along that coast now. On our first morning, the only animals we saw were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the fog made it hard to see far, so I just enjoyed watching the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t know. It was nice to forget about time and just enjoy the moment. We always remembered to have lunch and dinner, which we cooked together over campfires. At night, we slept on the boats. Even though the beds were hard, it felt great to live without stress!
