Journal-based peer review is the process where experts check a scientific research paper before it is published. This process is seen as important for ensuring the quality of research. It is supposed to stop bad or silly papers from being published. However, reviewing a paper can take a long time, sometimes up to a year. Is this delay worth it? The answer is both yes and no. 

I still believe that papers should be checked before they are published, but I see changes happening. More researchers are using preprints, which are drafts of papers shared online without peer review. Preprints help researchers share new findings quickly so others can read and discuss them. 

Publishing in journals has become more about gaining fame and advancing careers. This focus can change the motivations of authors and reviewers. Scientists often compete to publish in top journals, which can lead to great research. But the pressure to publish in these journals can also lead to shortcuts, where important data is left out. Reviewers now often decide if a paper is good enough for a journal rather than if it is good research. For top journals, the decision can depend on how interesting or newsworthy the paper is, not just its scientific quality.

Many people know about these problems, but few want to change the current system. However, some experts believe that preprints could help solve these issues without changing everything. Preprints have been around for twenty years, but not all scientists use them. Some think that journals will not accept papers that have been shared as preprints. There is also a worry that publishing papers without peer review could lead to bad science, but this has not happened yet.

Preprints may not be peer-reviewed, but authors know that their work will be open to feedback from a global community of reviewers. For example, Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience. She wrote a paper that criticized another published paper. In traditional journals, the original authors could block her paper or complain about it. But by using a preprint, both sides could share their views openly, allowing readers to judge the arguments themselves. 

Preprint archives allow scientists to discuss their work informally on a larger scale. They can also be a good place to share negative results, which are often ignored by journals that focus only on new discoveries. Additionally, papers on preprint archives are read and cited more often, showing that sharing work this way is effective. By using the internet's openness and the collaborative spirit of the scientific community, preprints can help shift the focus back to the research itself, rather than where it is published.

When I ask my literature students what a poem is, they often say it is "a painting in words." But this answer usually does not satisfy anyone. One day, I asked a group of students to pick an object and write two paragraphs about it. One paragraph was to describe the object like a scientist, and the other was to be from the object's point of view, titled "Poem." One student wrote about an oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class understand how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise was fun and led to interesting discussions.

When I was in school, I found poetry confusing. I thought every poem was a silly puzzle that made it hard to understand feelings. After school, many people pay less attention to poetry. Sometimes, you see a poem, and it stands out because it is not like regular writing. It challenges you to read it, but often you feel let down because it is boring or hard to understand. 

What do we want from the poems we read? We might expect them to express deep feelings, beautiful images, or clever thoughts. But if we want tears, we watch movies; if we want information, we read articles. Novels take us to different worlds, and music combines words and melodies in a way that is hard to beat. 

However, one thing that poems can do is show us ambiguity, which is common in everyday life. But this still does not explain what a poem really is. If you look up "poem" online, it leads you to "poetry," which is described as a type of art that uses the beauty and rhythm of language. This is a complicated definition. The word "poem" comes from the Greek word "poí?ma," which means "a thing made," and a poet is someone who makes things. So, if a poem is a "thing made," what kind of thing is it?

Some poets compare poems to wild animals, which are unpredictable, or to machines, which are precise. But these comparisons can break down when we think about them closely. The best part of trying to define a poem through comparison is the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this can change how you think about both. It can help us see ordinary things in a new way.

We often remember song lyrics, showing how powerful the mix of words and music can be. A poem on a page can have a strong impact, even though it looks like the prose around it. The empty space around a poem could have been used for a longer article or an ad. A poem is written and rewritten like any article or story, but it is not usually made to be sold. Publishers promote poetry collections, but they do not expect them to make money. A poem exists for its own sake, and because of its special place in a magazine or book, it can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. £70 was a lot of money back then, and I could have spent it on something useful for our home. However, my wife, Marion, was very impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first trip. Over the years, every brooch and coin I found made me happy because it connected me to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years before I found something that impressed Marion again.

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a closer spot where I knew there were old farming tools. When my detector beeped for the first time, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it, but I couldn’t walk away without checking. I dug down half a meter and lay in the mud when I saw a round, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get my hopes up. But as I cleaned it, I saw it was a thick, beautifully designed loop. I stopped and stared, remembering to breathe. I had seen something like this before at the British Museum. It was called a torc, a famous necklace from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. The word "torc" means "twist," and it is made of gold and silver, with a gold ring at each end.

I took it to my car and looked at it on the way home. I rinsed it in my kitchen sink, which was probably the first time it had been cleaned in a long time. “Marion!” I shouted, “I have something for you.” When she came in, she stopped and asked, “What is it?” I told her it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn’t try it on because we were afraid of damaging it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. I was worried about it being stolen, so I eventually took it out, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there.

The law says I must report such finds to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as I could before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned around, stopped talking, and was surprised. The torc was confirmed as real and was sold to my local council. It is now in the British Museum in London. I received £350,000, which was shared between the owner of the field and me. 

But the torc means more to me than just money. I feel like I have saved something important for the country. People often say to me, “Now that you found something so amazing, will you stop detecting?” But I still find brooches and coins interesting. Just like a fisherman who catches a big fish, I won’t stop searching while there’s a chance to find something even bigger tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things about traveling, but I don’t talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends share their carefully planned trips with lots of activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and don’t say much. What would they think if they knew that my travel plans often include time for naps during the day and relaxing mornings in nice beds? 

Sleeping better is one of the nice surprises of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how many hours I slept—more than 12 hours most days. There were loud birds nearby, but it didn’t bother me. Away from home and my own bed, I could sleep deeply and enjoyably. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, it was easier to sleep. 

I believe that sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we see, hear, and smell new things. All these new experiences fill our minds, and when we sleep, we process them. This is why sleep can feel so much deeper when we are traveling. 

People often worry about jet lag, but I think the challenges I face after long trips are more about adjusting to new places and cultures than just time changes. For example, in Trinidad, people wake up very early to avoid the heat, slow down around 10 a.m. when the sun is strong, and then become active again in the cool evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to get used to their different sleep patterns. When I finally adjust, I feel like I have truly arrived.

I remember one afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. I had a big lunch with new friends in an apartment with a view of the beautiful Caribbean Sea. After eating, we all felt sleepy and the conversation faded. One by one, my friends went to lie down on hammocks and sofas. I understood then why they had so many pillows around. I took some pillows and joined them. I had heard about the Latin American tradition of the siesta, but that day I really experienced it. I shared not just sleep, but a part of Dominican life.

Travel sleep has another great quality: I remember it. Being away from home, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds that fill my mind while I sleep. If the idea of ‘slow travel’—enjoying every moment instead of rushing—is what makes a modern traveler aware, then sleep is the slowest activity of all. Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed about my love for sleep and tell my ambitious friends that travel sleep is an important part of the experience too.

The woman turned away from the mirror and asked, “What do you think? Be honest.” Mia picked up a nice hat with a soft layer of fabric and a silk bow. “I still think this one looks best on you,” she said politely. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a funny face. “But it’s so boring,” she replied. “Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This beautiful little hat will make me stand out.” She touched the small red and black top hat on her head. “Yes, this is the one I want,” she decided. 

Mia smiled and agreed that the woman would stand out at the wedding. She thought about her own daughter, Jen, who was turning thirty today. They were having a family gathering, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious to meet Jen’s friend, Tattie, whom they didn’t know much about. When Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, Mia’s husband, Jeff, had reacted quickly. “Tattie? What kind of name is that?” he asked. “It’s short for Tatiana,” Mia explained. “I think it’s nice.” Jeff thought it sounded pretentious. He didn’t like anything showy and often told Mia she was too polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat and that a trash can lid would look better on her.

An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered her home, Medlar House, which was just a short walk away. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, moved out, Mia decided to turn the empty barn next to their house into a space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. “Do you really think people want to buy hats?” he asked. But Mia knew from her friends that many women had trouble finding the perfect hat for special occasions. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became successful. Women came from far away to her shop in Little Pelham, where she made them feel welcome and allowed them to try on as many hats as they wanted. She encouraged customers to bring their outfits to make sure everything matched. Recently, she also started selling handbags and costume jewelry.

It’s a long way from London to Atlanta, and in his new American home, Lawrence Okoye thinks about his amazing sports journey. He feels confident but is surprised by how far he has come, from competing in the Olympic final in discus to possibly playing American football. Even though he has never played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen for one of the big teams in the USA.

In Atlanta, Lawrence is still learning about his new position in football. It is surprising that a 21-year-old who is new to the sport could be selected for one of the biggest teams in American sports. But Lawrence is good at proving people wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law, but he decided to focus on training for discus instead of going to school. After just 20 months of training, he became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world.

Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather training for discus because he wanted to prepare for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in American football, he said, “It was in the back of my mind, but I only decided to try it when I got to the USA.” He had thought about it while in school in London, but it seemed like a crazy idea at the time. After arriving in America, he learned about the NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played football, he thought he could be good enough to attend the trials. “Pretty much,” he said when asked if he believed he could make it.

When asked if he was nervous about being tested with experienced players, he said, “No, not at all. I don’t get nervous for many things.” He is not very talkative, but he is sure of his abilities. His performance in various tests showed that he was the most impressive player. “I was very happy to hear that,” he said, showing a bit of pride.

However, he is also cautious. He has no experience in football, so how can he make it into an NFL team? He said, “Coaches have told me I have the right skills. It’s all about how hard I work.” When asked if he would be calm while waiting to hear if he was selected, he replied, “I will be. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I will be chosen, but I’m not too worried.”

This calmness might come from his disappointing experience in the Olympic discus final, where he came in last. He seems to have moved on from that moment and is proud that he qualified for the final with a great last throw. “That was an amazing day,” he said. “The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sports. I can always return to it.”

After his Olympic disappointment, some people thought that he let the experience affect him. Lawrence does not want to talk about it. An NFL player’s minimum salary is over $400,000 a year, so there are clear financial reasons to play. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With all his physical talent, wouldn’t it be better to focus on just one sport? “I understand why someone would say that,” he replied. “I’m trying to achieve something I’ve dreamed about since I was a kid. If it doesn’t work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought out.”

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see that it was already morning. Looking out of the window, I saw the empty land below. The dark shades of brown and green made me feel better because, even though it was mid-September, it was still summer in Siberia. I could see no signs of people, just mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. 

My neighbor woke up and smiled at me. “Good morning, Robert,” he said slowly with a Russian accent. His name was Sergei, and he was a salesman from Moscow. He was flying to sell safety clothing to the local mining companies. His English was not very good, and my Russian was not great either, but we used a dictionary to talk. I told him I was going to the city of Magadan in far-eastern Siberia with a one-way ticket because I planned to ride my bicycle back home to England. 

“But, Robert,” he said, “there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle.” I explained that I thought there was a road, but not many people used it. “Alone?” he asked, pointing at me. “No, I will ride with a friend named Al.” “Just one friend?” he asked. “Yes, just one,” I nodded. Sergei still looked unsure and pointed outside, saying “Holodna” (cold). I tried to show him with my hands that I had warm clothes, but I didn’t mention that I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and gear were bought at low prices. I wasn’t sure if they would be good enough, especially my big postman’s trousers that I bought for £10.

It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. That morning, the hall was full of tired students. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer was talking on and on. I was thinking about a question. Should I ask him or not? “Well, why not?” I wrote a note to my old school friend Al, who was sitting in front of me. I asked him if he wanted to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China that summer. He read my note, thought for a moment, wrote something back, and passed it to me. It said, “OK.” 

Now, six years later, I was going to meet Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher. The job was challenging but also rewarding, and I had long holidays to go on adventures. Twice, I had used these holidays to visit Al. After our bike ride in Pakistan, Al caught the adventure bug and decided to cycle around the world. Since then, he had taken on bigger and bigger challenges. This trip around the world by bike was his biggest yet. Sometimes he thought the ride would be too hard for him, but I envied him. He was having an amazing adventure and facing new challenges every day. He was proving the doubters wrong and doing something that scared him, which made him feel alive.

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots race through tall pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, do barrel rolls, and loops while flying at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to be part of this race. 

An hour before my flight, I had to sign two forms. The first form said I was healthy, and the second said I would empty my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay aware of my surroundings. I was told, “The horizon is your best friend,” and the pilot would tell me where to look. I also had to promise to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was told not to touch anything during the flight. When we started moving down the runway, I was nervous. My legs were up, my feet were away from the important pedals, and my hands stayed away from the switches. I decided I would not relax and enjoy the flight. This is a challenge in high-speed flying. To stay safe, you need to be calm and focused. You must know when to tense up and when to relax. Panicking is not a good idea.

As we took off, the pilot, Dario, and I quickly turned to the right. It was a sudden move, and I felt the air leave my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and gasped as I sank into my seat. For a moment, I felt like I weighed 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out and made another sharp turn, diving down. I felt my stomach drop as we flew low, just 10 meters above the ground, aiming for a small space between two pylons. We passed them at 400 km per hour, and I felt excited, but then we turned sharply again.

For two minutes, I got to fly the plane, but my hands were shaking so much that the plane shook too. Then Dario said something, but I couldn’t hear him. Instead of answering, he did a barrel roll, turning the plane completely upside down. He asked if I was okay, and I said yes. He then asked if I had enough, and I lied and said no. After that, he did a loop, flying up and over in a full circle. 

I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. But for me, it was too much. At the top of the loop, while we were upside down, I heard a voice saying, “Relax, relax, look up.” I looked up and saw some fields. The flight lasted 10 minutes, and it felt easy compared to what the pilots experience during the race. When we landed, Dario happily ate sandwiches, but I didn’t eat for hours. That night, I kept dreaming about the loop over and over again.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have ever seen amazing videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, it is likely that he filmed them. He says his favorite temperature is -18°C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first love, where he learned how to survive in cold environments. His big opportunity came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where he was working, to make a wildlife documentary. He helped the crew find different locations, and after 48 hours, he realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for him: it included travel, adventure, and underwater experiences.

Now, he is a well-known cameraman and has worked on many important TV wildlife series. He started his career at a good time because not many people had been to Antarctica. There were people who filmed coral, elephants, and chimpanzees, but he became known as the "cold man." He felt that many amazing scenes were waiting to be filmed.

When he began 35 years ago, the camera and communication technology were very simple. He says, "It is much easier to film today. Back then, if you filmed something, you had to remember it. Now, with digital technology, you can film a lot and see it right away. You had to think about what shots you needed next and what you missed. You filmed less because film was very expensive. Today, you can have too much footage."

Allan believes his experience in cold conditions is very valuable. He has spent so much time on sea ice that it feels normal to him. He does get cold toes, but he says the poles are healthy places with no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes. Wildlife filming has many successes, but also failures and embarrassing moments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes, but he could not identify the birds.

Recently, Allan got permission to film in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. He knew it would be a tough job because it is home to polar bears and is very dangerous. In April, the temperature is usually -32°C, and the wind is strong, making it hard to carry cameras in deep snow. After walking for five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens for 23 days, he had only seen one mother bear and her cub. However, on the 24th day, he felt like he was in the world of bears, moving and sensing like them. 

He describes how they would find a new hole and wait, moving around to stay warm. After five hours of watching, he finally saw a brief glimpse of a bear. The camera was ready, and he quickly focused on the viewfinder. After a few seconds, he saw a black nose, then the bear's head, and soon she was resting in front of the hole. She looked at him but did not seem worried. Just as he thought it could not get better, she slid down the slope, and then two cubs appeared at the den entrance. He felt like they were watching a special show.

Now, Allan wants to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic. He wants to talk to the people who live there and see how it affects their lives. He believes he could create an amazing documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. He had to swim in very cold water, deal with frostbite, and avoid polar bears. Eight months later, he also reached the South Pole. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for a new adventure that he says is even bigger. Explorers like Pen are confident and determined. This time, however, there is a lot more at stake. Pen and two friends will go on a three-month journey of 1,000 kilometers to the North Pole. They will measure the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and Pen knows the results will be very important for scientists. This work will show how global warming is affecting the ice in the polar region.

Pen was prepared for this job since he was a child. His father’s old nanny, who worked for the famous polar explorer Scott of the Antarctic, helped him become strong. She sent him out into the Scottish mountains during storms with very few clothes. His father also loved adventures in cold places, and Pen grew up to be very strong. 

Pen is married to Mary, who loves horses and the outdoors. She helps him with his polar guide business. Mary says she worries more about him when he is at home because he often thinks about the Arctic. For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where horse riders compete with runners. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. They live in the countryside with their two children. Pen says it is harder to be away from them this time. When he last left, his son was only one year old, and he told him to take care of his mother and sister. His son took this very seriously and kept asking how they were, which became too much for him. Pen thinks it was not fair to put that pressure on his son.

For this trip, Pen plans to have little contact with his family while he is in the Arctic. He believes that calling them will remind them of how far away he is. In the days before he leaves, he is carefully preparing his equipment. He says that when you are on the ice, it is very hard to fix things or do anything complicated. 

He will be joined by Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a team of six people to help them by flying in supplies. Pen finds being part of a team stressful, and he is also worried about his age. He will turn 47 soon and feels he has not trained enough. He says that organizing everything has taken more time than he expected, and he is nervous about what he will have to do.

Pen believes that this mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge that drove explorers in the past. He admits that reaching the North Pole was a personal goal, but this time, the scientists will benefit from the information they collect. They want to involve as many people as possible in understanding what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. Pen feels that their skills, which may seem strange, are now very important and useful.

I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the chance to do more writing, TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. Even though I enjoyed these activities, I wanted something competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay in shape so I could try for another Olympic spot if I felt inspired again. So, I signed up for marathons and triathlons. 

But then, I remembered Ben Fogle, a TV presenter, who kept asking me, “Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?” I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I missed that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they were not very excited. I knew that if I entered the race, I would want to win, even though it was called an adventure. 

I thought about whether rowing with Ben would help me win. Maybe not. But being an underdog without pressure sounded nice. I contacted Ben. He was going to join the race anyway and had found a way to pay the big entry fee and deposit for a boat. This made the race feel real, not just a dream. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000, which is a lot of money. We believed we had a good chance, but we still needed to work hard to get it.

Besides the race costs, I also had to think about losing money because I would be away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money after being a professional athlete. It feels good that people are interested in what I have done. But I find it hard to talk about my past without having a new goal. Joining the race would mean I was not just talking about what I did before; I would be doing something exciting again: rowing across the Atlantic.

I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one big lesson was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My training for the Olympics was hard, but it was also simple. I trained almost every day, but I had a set program and support from doctors and dieticians. I was worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I thought it might look like I just wanted to be on TV, instead of choosing a better partner to win the race. 

However, my worries went away as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing; it’s also about mental strength. Ben had done tough challenges before, like the Marathon des Sables, and spent time at sea and on a deserted island. But he didn’t know how to row well. I was surprised by how little he understood about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more understanding, but I felt it was important to tell him how much he needed to improve. I should have known what to expect when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of cold, empty landscapes, maybe because I was tired of the noise and crowds of London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They offered me a job as a husky dog handler for the busy winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, for trips that can last from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. Recently, they took over another place called the "wilderness farm," which is beautiful but basic, with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months, but I needed to know what I was getting into. "The hours are long, the conditions are tough, and the work is very physical," they said. I started packing right away.

On November 6, I flew from London. I found myself staring at a page with more than 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names, but I felt distracted and nervous. I put the page down and looked out the window instead. I thought about how spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. But now, I saw winter moving south, and rivers freezing.

On November 7, I took a bus north. It was everything I hoped for. We drove through dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes for reindeer to cross the road. I arrived at the farm after dark. As soon as I walked in, I was given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. "Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?" Anna asked. I followed the sound of barking, which got louder as I reached the dogsheds. Three people were running around, getting the huskies ready for sleds. The dogs were very excited, pulling against their ropes. I could barely introduce myself because everyone was too busy. I stood to the side and petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone told me to "Get in!" and I almost fell into the nearest sled. A command was shouted, and we took off into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

By November 15, I was starting to learn how to be a husky guide, but first, I had to answer questions about what I could do. "Are you useful?" Anna asked. I was confused. I didn’t know. After more questions, I realized I wasn’t very useful: I had never driven a snowmobile, hadn’t done woodwork since school, and had never chopped anything with an axe. "You do have a driving license?" someone asked. I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I learned the basics of dog-sledding quickly: lean into the corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. But other tasks were complicated. Simple things like feeding and watering the dogs were hard in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a "soup" of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, I was overwhelmed with instructions, and my muscles hurt from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled around by excited huskies. But I felt proud. I emailed my friends, saying, "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw, in the snow!"

On that day, when Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters came to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was good enough to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a special treatment called emu oil, which Olympic gold medalist Cathy Freeman had suggested to help Radcliffe heal from an injury caused by an accident when she hit a bike while training. Radcliffe said that she didn’t fully realize how big her achievement was at the time. She felt it was just what she was meant to do that day, so it didn’t feel special to her then. She and her team had decided not to set any limits on what they could achieve, and their motto was "no limits."

During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried that she might not be able to keep up her fast pace and might drop out of the race. Hartmann was angry about this, but he understood that people who didn’t know how fit Radcliffe was might think it was risky to start so quickly.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to think about her time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers very fast, but she still managed to sprint the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a long time. Radcliffe thought, "I will come back and do it next year," and she really believed she could.

Unfortunately, that did not happen. After the race, everyone wanted to know how Radcliffe, who had an unusual running style, had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with Radcliffe for weeks, helping her with her training as she ran 250-300 kilometers each week. He said, "I’ve worked with 63 Olympic medalists, and no one could handle the pain like she could. She would make me work hard because I had to go deep into her muscles."

Hartmann described how he would travel 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training place in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no time for greetings or tea; Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour training session. Hartmann said, "Paula would push you to your limits, and that’s what made her so good." He spent so much time with Radcliffe that other athletes he worked with became jealous.

When asked why no one has come close to her record, Radcliffe said, "I trained really hard, but there are more talented people out there." She thought someone like Mary Keitany, a two-time London marathon winner, might break her record. Radcliffe explained that some runners focus more on competing against each other than on improving themselves. She believed that her strong mental focus helped her push herself to run faster, as she never thought she could relax during the race.

Radcliffe did not know it at the time, but that marathon was the best performance of her career. She would never run that fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. There was a lot of talk about a food ‘revolution’ happening in Britain, and I believed we had created a series that added something new to it. However, I worried if people would like a cooking show that included not just cooking techniques but also history and science. I watched the first episode feeling both happy and nervous. I didn’t need to worry. The show became very successful and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant.

In each project, I felt like I was on a journey, whether it was exploring the past, understanding cooking techniques, or learning about people. I wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each one linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving travel and new experiences. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who makes golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent many years trying to reach their own idea of perfection.

Perfection is different for everyone. Choosing which dishes to include in the series was very difficult, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was not included. I could imagine people asking, “Where is steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?” But after a long meeting, the TV team and I created a list that would please many people. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on their feelings, memories, and experiences.

Even though the book is called ‘Perfection’, I knew I wouldn’t say that the recipes were the best or final. I believed that by using my cooking skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, chefs, and their customers, I could find out what makes these dishes special. The dictionary says ‘perfection’ means being perfect, but it also means improving through practice and trying new ideas until you create something unique.

The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen before. I was excited to learn about food and memories because I started my career in the same way. Finding the best ingredients took me all over the world. I had many adventures, like visiting a canning factory that was using the wrong tomatoes and going to a dairy farm that was not good enough for filming. I even tried new cooking techniques, like hand-milking a cow to make ice cream and using a hospital machine to cook chicken, which almost caused a fire while trying to make a real Neapolitan pizza.

We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, went off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the engine. He looked at it for a long time with his hands in his pockets and a serious look on his face. “Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,” he finally said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field was big and empty, just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, because it was better to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything they talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound very sure. “Liar.” I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought about it, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. 

John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind and waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “It’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it got dark. Mum took out blankets and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said. 

Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept thinking about how we would get home now that our van had to be towed. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city named Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke good English. They discussed the music they were playing and their recent travels. 

“I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said. It sounded impressive, but she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world. Because of this, she missed so much school that she wasn’t officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She was one of the lucky few chosen from thousands of applicants. At the celebration, her dad gave her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her. Her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took Lucy out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself. Her mother had filled out the form and sent in a CD. “I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought her mom just didn’t want to give her a chance to say no. Back then, Lucy believed that making waves was bad, so she didn’t think about trying to get out of it.

The guy from Tokyo leaned in, surprised. “Tanglewood?” he asked. “Yeah.” “How old are you?” “Fifteen.” He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy didn’t mean to brag. It was hard to know when to share her achievements and when to keep quiet. “It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're trying...” Liesel/Louisa then looked across the room and said she had to go talk to someone. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, messy hair, like many musicians, to show they were cool. “Once, when I was about eight,” Lucy replied. 

Just then, Lucy's grandfather came over. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone.” He took her arm and pulled her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They’re not the competition,” Lucy said. “Everyone is the competition,” her grandfather replied. He took her around the room to meet important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what was said.

Later, in the elevator to their suite, her grandfather said, “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” Lucy liked that. She enjoyed being recognized, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from the kids at her old school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play a difficult piece by Rachmaninov. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

“It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,” said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I wanted to see what experts say about this. I found some interesting information. 

Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have a lot of real-life friends, feel good about themselves, and are learning important skills for the digital world. Simon Miles, an expert on online safety, says that social networking is a big part of growing up today. Teenagers use social media differently than adults. They don’t just check things quickly; they are part of it. This can be good or bad, but it depends on how you use it.

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media expert, says it is like the youth clubs that parents used to go to. It helps teenagers connect with friends, share jokes, and talk about their lives. It also helps them learn about themselves and deal with teenage problems.

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says that during adolescence, we often ask ourselves, “Who am I?” Social networking can help with this. You can share your favorite music or sports and see how others think differently. Research shows that teenagers who use social media a lot are not more self-centered than those who don’t. He also says that for shy people, talking online can be easier than in person, and it helps them practice social skills.

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes these sites can help quiet people with special interests connect with others who like the same things. For example, if you are one of the few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a group online with similar interests, you can feel more connected and popular in a different way.

Pauline White, an expert in digital education, shared something interesting: teenagers who find new interests online and join groups of people with similar interests are really using social networks well. She thinks social networking is becoming a way for teenagers to be creative. They are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what they like. Photo-sharing sites help photographers connect, learn new skills, and share their work. This can help them get jobs in the future because businesses use social media to sell products and reach customers. 

If you have many friends on social networks, they can be potential customers for your products. Teenagers who use social media creatively will benefit when they grow up and start working. Matthews agrees that many sites allow people to work together to create and share content. Working together is an important skill in today’s job market.

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a part of Canada. But my parents wanted to do something different for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to plan a big family trip, which my twin brother and I were not very excited about. They often said, “Not enough people do this anymore,” while we exchanged worried looks.

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, food, and clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough space left in the car, we started our “Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our big home for smaller places for the next five thousand miles made me wonder what we were getting into.

We drove west through Oklahoma. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, where we saw beautiful stars, but we almost got blown off the road by a dust storm. We learned that cows have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. We saw deserts turn into mountains. Each day felt similar, but we still had unique experiences. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and visited Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where we noticed a strong smell of sulfur. As we climbed to our next stop, we realized that the roads meant for Jeeps were not for us.

Every place we visited showed a mix of old and new. We often got stuck in traffic because of construction. We laughed when we saw big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. On our way to Yellowstone National Park, we saw many wind farms and watched the sunset over bear habitats. We even experienced “bear jams,” where traffic stopped to let bears cross the road, creating unforgettable memories.

As we drove, life at home felt far away. Even the old hotel we stayed in, which had no internet or cell phone service, couldn’t ruin our fun. It was a 95-year-old building, but the views were amazing. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right; you don’t need to go to a faraway place to find something special.

It was nice to be home together again, and I was happy that my brother and I didn’t fight during our long trip. We took three thousand photos of our adventures, and I knew I would remember the unexpected and fun moments the most.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy needed to finish her last year of school, so it was better for her to stay. She was happy because she got the best room at her college, which had its own kitchen and study area. She also had free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would check on Amy, whether she liked it or not.

Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only remembered a few happy times with Daisy from when she was younger, and she never knew her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not very excited, but Daisy was happy to have Rose with her. Rose didn’t understand why her parents didn’t get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Because of this, Rose spent her summers away from Daisy.

Dahlia told Rose that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and loved to bring people together. Rose expected to get many dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon, which made her smile. Daisy was not like a typical old lady; she seemed to go to more events than anyone else.

Before moving, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But she wanted one thing: her independence. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission. She felt she could be trusted to do these things. She didn’t want to be reminded about homework or staying out late, and she didn’t want to be taken everywhere by her grandmother. Daisy understood.

Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone for emergencies only, and Rose was very happy. They all agreed to trust each other. Daisy would trust Rose to make good choices, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too strict. If either of them went too far, they would talk about it again.

Rose was not a wild child. Her few friends were similar, so her school reports were always good. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This would be her fourth school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this would be her last school, as she would be starting her final two years. For Rose, this was a new beginning in her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher first thought she might write a novel. She said, "I believed writing a book would be a big achievement because it seemed very challenging. I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When I turned 13, I decided to try writing a book." Now, the novel she started at that age is about to be published. 

Charlotte recently told her former teacher about her book, and the teacher was surprised. She thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40 years old. Charlotte didn’t understand why she should wait to do something she was good at.

It is a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a great achievement: it has a strong story and is full of action. Nothing about it, except for the age of the main character, shows that it was written by a teenager. 

A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she doesn’t. She is confident, smart, and steady, which keeps her from being overly confident. Charlotte understands that she is still young. When I ask her about the complex moral questions in her book, she says, "I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers." She laughs and adds, "I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t think I’m very wise. I just wanted to explore the idea of taking responsibility."

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are often shown in books. She believes there are three types of teenagers in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who struggles socially. She found it frustrating to read about these types. "What if you’re just fine? There aren’t many stories about teenagers who are okay in some way. Some writers give the impression that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience. This can hurt their self-confidence."

Charlotte loves reading famous fantasy authors, but their books almost stopped her from writing. "These books explore deep topics about life and psychology. I wondered if I needed to write like that to create a good book and if I could do it." However, she appreciates a book called How Not to Write a Novel. "It says that if the reader starts to guess what will happen, the suspense is probably gone."

Some might think that Charlotte’s parents, who are both journalists, helped her get her novel published. Her father knew someone in publishing who read her book first. Charlotte knows she is lucky because it is hard for anyone to get their first novel read, no matter their age. "Every writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you are on your own. In the end, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted," Charlotte concludes.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then a guy named David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He went up the ramp quickly and flew into the air, but something seemed wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and fell into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said kindly, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ 

I thought maybe freestyle skiing was not for me. On past skiing holidays, I enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t like those teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I was afraid I would look silly trying to join them. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps covered in fake snow. Students jumped and tried their new tricks, landing in foam pits – not a real introduction to skiing outside. 

After practicing indoors, we went outside to try our skills. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. Gareth explained, ‘Before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best. But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope goes down to the landing zone. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which is safer. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important.

At first, it was hard to make my body go fast towards the jump. My legs wanted to slow down, and I often landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday, I felt exhausted. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. 

On the second day, we started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors, but bouncing was fun. Some exercises copied ski-jumping moves, while others helped us learn ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing while in the air. Gareth gave us tips. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – I only noticed the moment before take-off and then found myself in the foam cubes next to the trampoline.

We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes, but I finally landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of my achievement. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I made myself keep my speed up as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed correctly. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope, no longer attached to my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster in an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you hold on tightly as the ride stops. You take a deep breath before the carriage slowly goes up. Then, suddenly, it drops, and your stomach feels like it is in the air. You go fast forward, turn left, and even go upside down. You scream in fear, but you chose to be there, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks.

It is interesting that amusement parks, with their exciting rides, are a big business. Many creative people work behind the scenes, including engineers and designers, to make these rides safe and thrilling. The job of a rollercoaster designer might sound like a child's dream, but it is actually very challenging. They must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping riders safe. They also need to create new experiences to keep visitors coming back.

Most of the ideas for rollercoasters today were created by a designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. In the past, rides were more extreme, but now designers must follow certain rules and use specific designs from ride manufacturers. I talked to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a "thrill engineer," said that the skill is in putting all the parts together. Dr. John Roberts explained that it is important to quickly switch between feelings of excitement and safety so that riders feel thrilled but not scared.

To create an amazing ride, teams must come up with a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and combine it with exciting features like tall heights and steep drops. However, Professor Walker said that in creative work, experience and testing are very important. Jeff Hornick, a senior director in theme park development, agreed that it helps to love thrills when designing rollercoasters to understand what riders want.

I asked if rollercoaster designers will use new technology like virtual reality. Walker said we should not expect too much from it. He believes that while new technology can make rides more exciting, the real experience of being on a rollercoaster will always be the most important part for many years to come.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has done a lot as a choreographer. She has created dances for many theatres and dance companies, and she still dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both things with her busy schedule. She says, "Dancing again helps me remember what it’s like to be in the studio, following the orders of strict choreographers. It can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers sometimes forget how hard it is to rehearse all day."

As a choreographer, Miranda teaches and enjoys working with young students. She explains, "Beginners are often open to new ideas. Working with them can be easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed but don’t always know their strengths and weaknesses. This makes them open to criticism, even if it’s tough. Sometimes they challenge me, and I appreciate their honest feedback."

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. She says, "There might be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to the music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I wish I could experiment more and change the music to improve the mood during tough rehearsals. But now, I mostly work on big productions where the music is already decided."

Miranda believes in meeting new people and not sticking to one place. She says, "It’s important to make new contacts. But I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I need to adapt my work each time I go somewhere new, so I don’t get stuck in my ways."

We talk about a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says, "Many past documentaries looked glamorous but were not true. This one shows real life in a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized that feeling. She knows she’s not doing it right but can’t make her body move as needed. It’s hard to watch, but it’s real. People often underestimate the hard work and dedication in ballet."

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. She replies, "It’s when everything comes together – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers. Perfection is hard to achieve, but aiming high is important. It helps you get away with some mistakes. I’ve worked on shows where the dance was great, but the costumes or props were distracting, and that’s disappointing."

Miranda has done many different types of work, so I ask how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? She says, "People want to label you, but I don’t understand that. There’s a trend to focus on one area of expertise, but I don’t follow that. Maybe one day I will be known for one thing, but for now, I want to explore more."

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that TV shows many amazing things, but I think it is better to go out and experience the world. This conversation inspired me to take a fun four-day trip and make a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs.

A friend was giving away his old sofa, and I decided to use it in my film. I added three wheels and some cables to it, which I connected to old seatbelts that I wore over my shoulders. I put my luggage on the sofa and even slept on it at night, including one night on the beach. Some friends joined me during the trip, helping to pull the sofa and cheering me on.

I have done many walking trips in the past, but this was very different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads. This allowed me to stop at cafés and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of sitting on a rock with my sandwiches blowing away in the wind.

I often had to tell people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share my experience of dragging a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talking about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried group trips before. My brother, who I usually travel with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a ticket for one person, because the islands are popular with families. I told him I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would join ten other people to swim around the small islands. He still looked confused, but he smiled and let me on the ferry.

Before we started, our group had exchanged emails, but there was not much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides told us that a support boat would follow us, and they made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first long swim of 1.5 km. I felt nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swum in rivers, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first swim, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The next days followed a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the beautiful views. As the swims got longer, I also got faster and enjoyed them more. I felt like I didn’t need the support boat anymore. I can’t wait to come back again next year!

Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it has many rewards. Since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have a lot of free time, and my life is always interesting. This makes it a great job for someone young like me!

When I was a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family. I often flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to the passengers. Some of them let me help. This experience stayed in my mind when I wanted to change from my banking job and look for something new.

At the interview for the flight attendant job, there were many young people, and many of us were accepted. Most of us had good qualifications and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I talked about my skills and past work experience, not just my love for travel, which everyone else said. Because of this, I got the job!

I would recommend this job to anyone because there are many good things about it. The free flights are nice, but they are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: "No one is finished until everyone is finished." It feels like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close.

When I am not working, I don’t have to take my work home. If I do have difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!

At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy seeing the children do things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some kids feel nervous at first, but with some encouragement, they try it and all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel very happy.

At the start of the week, some children miss their homes. It is not the youngest ones who feel this way the most; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We do not let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it is too late to call now and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and at the end of the week, they all come to thank us because they had a great time.

Sometimes, it is not just the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who call all the time to ask how their child is doing, which is not really needed. Often, their child is busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to tell the parents to call back later.

We often see a certain type of child who comes to camp, usually wearing expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why it is important.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the ‘Best Musical’ award four times! However, doing the show with an all-British cast was not easy. In the UK, there are more rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in London. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors from the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award.

The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night. Many people want to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He told me that the young actors are very busy. ‘We have regular school lessons at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends,’ he said. 

I asked Jamie what his classmates thought of the show. He replied, ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them.’ When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes!

Even though the young actors were already musicians and some played several instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
